Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very
likely it can talk: at any rate, there\xE2\x80\x99s no harm in trying.\xE2\x80\x99 So she
began: \xE2\x80\x98O Mouse, do you know the way out of this pool? I am very tired
of swimming about here, O Mouse!\xE2\x80\x99 (Alice thought this must be the right
way of speaking to a mouse: she had never done such a thing before, but
she remembered having seen in her brother\xE2\x80\x99s Latin Grammar, \xE2\x80\x98A mouse--of
a mouse--to a mouse--a mouse--O mouse!\xE2\x80\x99) The Mouse looked at her rather
inquisitively, and seemed to her to wink with one of its little eyes,
but it said nothing.

\xE2\x80\x98Perhaps it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t understand English,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice; \xE2\x80\x98I daresay it\xE2\x80\x99s
a French mouse, come over with William the Conqueror.\xE2\x80\x99 (For, with all
her knowledge of history, Alice had no very clear notion how long ago
anything had happened.) So she began again: \xE2\x80\x98Ou est ma chatte?\xE2\x80\x99 which
was the first sentence in her French lesson-book. The Mouse gave a
sudden leap out of the water, and seemed to quiver all over with fright.
\xE2\x80\x98Oh, I beg your pardon!\xE2\x80\x99 cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt
the poor animal\xE2\x80\x99s feelings. \xE2\x80\x98I quite forgot you didn\xE2\x80\x99t like cats.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Not like cats!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice. \xE2\x80\x98Would
YOU like cats if you were me?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, perhaps not,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice in a soothing tone: \xE2\x80\x98don\xE2\x80\x99t be angry
about it. And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah: I think you\xE2\x80\x99d
take a fancy to cats if you could only see her. She is such a dear quiet
thing,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the
pool, \xE2\x80\x98and she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and
washing her face--and she is such a nice soft thing to nurse--and she\xE2\x80\x99s
such a capital one for catching mice--oh, I beg your pardon!\xE2\x80\x99 cried
Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she
felt certain it must be really offended. \xE2\x80\x98We won\xE2\x80\x99t talk about her any
more if you\xE2\x80\x99d rather not.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98We indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his
tail. \xE2\x80\x98As if I would talk on such a subject! Our family always HATED
cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don\xE2\x80\x99t let me hear the name again!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I won\xE2\x80\x99t indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of
conversation. \xE2\x80\x98Are you--are you fond--of--of dogs?\xE2\x80\x99 The Mouse did not
answer, so Alice went on eagerly: \xE2\x80\x98There is such a nice little dog near
our house I should like to show you! A little bright-eyed terrier, you
know, with oh, such long curly brown hair! And it\xE2\x80\x99ll fetch things when
you throw them, and it\xE2\x80\x99ll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts
of things--I can\xE2\x80\x99t remember half of them--and it belongs to a farmer,
you know, and he says it\xE2\x80\x99s so useful, it\xE2\x80\x99s worth a hundred pounds! He
says it kills all the rats and--oh dear!\xE2\x80\x99 cried Alice in a sorrowful
tone, \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid I\xE2\x80\x99ve offended it again!\xE2\x80\x99 For the Mouse was swimming
away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in
the pool as it went.

So she called softly after it, \xE2\x80\x98Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we
won\xE2\x80\x99t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don\xE2\x80\x99t like them!\xE2\x80\x99 When the
Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its
face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low
trembling voice, \xE2\x80\x98Let us get to the shore, and then I\xE2\x80\x99ll tell you my
history, and you\xE2\x80\x99ll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.\xE2\x80\x99

It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the
birds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a Dodo,
a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures. Alice led the
way, and the whole party swam to the shore.




CHAPTER III. A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale

They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank--the
birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close
to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.

The first question of course was, how to get dry again: they had a
consultation about this, and after a few minutes it seemed quite natural
to Alice to find herself talking familiarly with them, as if she had
known them all her life. Indeed, she had quite a long argument with the
Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, \xE2\x80\x98I am older than
you, and must know better\xE2\x80\x99; and this Alice would not allow without
knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to tell its
age, there was no more to be said.

At last the Mouse, who seemed to be a person of authority among them,
called out, \xE2\x80\x98Sit down, all of you, and listen to me! I\xE2\x80\x99LL soon make you
dry enough!\xE2\x80\x99 They all sat down at once, in a large ring, with the Mouse
in the middle. Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on it, for she felt
sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.

\xE2\x80\x98Ahem!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse with an important air, \xE2\x80\x98are you all ready? This
is the driest thing I know. Silence all round, if you please! \xE2\x80\x9CWilliam
the Conqueror, whose cause was favoured by the pope, was soon submitted
to by the English, who wanted leaders, and had been of late much
accustomed to usurpation and conquest. Edwin and Morcar, the earls of
Mercia and Northumbria--\xE2\x80\x9C\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Ugh!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Lory, with a shiver.

\xE2\x80\x98I beg your pardon!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse, frowning, but very politely: \xE2\x80\x98Did
you speak?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Not I!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Lory hastily.

\xE2\x80\x98I thought you did,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse. \xE2\x80\x98--I proceed. \xE2\x80\x9CEdwin and Morcar,
the earls of Mercia and Northumbria, declared for him: and even Stigand,
the patriotic archbishop of Canterbury, found it advisable--\xE2\x80\x9C\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Found WHAT?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duck.

\xE2\x80\x98Found IT,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mouse replied rather crossly: \xE2\x80\x98of course you know what
\xE2\x80\x9Cit\xE2\x80\x9D means.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I know what \xE2\x80\x9Cit\xE2\x80\x9D means well enough, when I find a thing,\xE2\x80\x99 said the
Duck: \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s generally a frog or a worm. The question is, what did the
archbishop find?\xE2\x80\x99

The Mouse did not notice this question, but hurriedly went on, \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x9C--found
it advisable to go with Edgar Atheling to meet William and offer him the
crown. William\xE2\x80\x99s conduct at first was moderate. But the insolence of his
Normans--\xE2\x80\x9D How are you getting on now, my dear?\xE2\x80\x99 it continued, turning
to Alice as it spoke.

\xE2\x80\x98As wet as ever,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice in a melancholy tone: \xE2\x80\x98it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t seem to
dry me at all.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98In that case,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, \xE2\x80\x98I move
that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic
remedies--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Speak English!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Eaglet. \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t know the meaning of half
those long words, and, what\xE2\x80\x99s more, I don\xE2\x80\x99t believe you do either!\xE2\x80\x99 And
the Eaglet bent down its head to hide a smile: some of the other birds
tittered audibly.

\xE2\x80\x98What I was going to say,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dodo in an offended tone, \xE2\x80\x98was, that
the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What IS a Caucus-race?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; not that she wanted much to know,
but the Dodo had paused as if it thought that SOMEBODY ought to speak,
and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.

\xE2\x80\x98Why,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dodo, \xE2\x80\x98the best way to explain it is to do it.\xE2\x80\x99 (And, as
you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell
you how the Dodo managed it.)

First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, [\xE2\x80\x98the exact
shape doesn\xE2\x80\x99t matter,\xE2\x80\x99 it said,) and then all the party were placed
along the course, here and there. There was no \xE2\x80\x98One, two, three, and
away,\xE2\x80\x99 but they began running when they liked, and left off when they
liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over. However,
when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again,
the Dodo suddenly called out \xE2\x80\x98The race is over!\xE2\x80\x99 and they all crowded
round it, panting, and asking, \xE2\x80\x98But who has won?\xE2\x80\x99

This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought,
and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead
(the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures
of him), while the rest waited in silence. At last the Dodo said,
\xE2\x80\x98EVERYBODY has won, and all must have prizes.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But who is to give the prizes?\xE2\x80\x99 quite a chorus of voices asked.

\xE2\x80\x98Why, SHE, of course,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger;
and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused
way, \xE2\x80\x98Prizes! Prizes!\xE2\x80\x99

Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her
pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had
not got into it), and handed them round as prizes. There was exactly one
a-piece all round.

\xE2\x80\x98But she must have a prize herself, you know,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course,\xE2\x80\x99 the Dodo replied very gravely. \xE2\x80\x98What else have you got in
your pocket?\xE2\x80\x99 he went on, turning to Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Only a thimble,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice sadly.

\xE2\x80\x98Hand it over here,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dodo.

Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly
presented the thimble, saying \xE2\x80\x98We beg your acceptance of this elegant
thimble\xE2\x80\x99; and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.

Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave
that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything
to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she
could.

The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and
confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste
theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back.
However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and
begged the Mouse to tell them something more.

\xE2\x80\x98You promised to tell me your history, you know,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98and why
it is you hate--C and D,\xE2\x80\x99 she added in a whisper, half afraid that it
would be offended again.

\xE2\x80\x98Mine is a long and a sad tale!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and
sighing.

\xE2\x80\x98It IS a long tail, certainly,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, looking down with wonder at
the Mouse\xE2\x80\x99s tail; \xE2\x80\x98but why do you call it sad?\xE2\x80\x99 And she kept on puzzling
about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was
something like this:--

         \xE2\x80\x98Fury said to a
         mouse, That he
        met in the
       house,
     \xE2\x80\x9CLet us
      both go to
       law: I will
        prosecute
         YOU.--Come,
           I\xE2\x80\x99ll take no
           denial; We
          must have a
        trial: For
      really this
     morning I\xE2\x80\x99ve
    nothing
    to do.\xE2\x80\x9D
      Said the
      mouse to the
       cur, \xE2\x80\x9CSuch
        a trial,
         dear Sir,
            With
          no jury
        or judge,
       would be
      wasting
      our
      breath.\xE2\x80\x9D
        \xE2\x80\x9CI\xE2\x80\x99ll be
        judge, I\xE2\x80\x99ll
         be jury,\xE2\x80\x9D
             Said
         cunning
          old Fury:
          \xE2\x80\x9CI\xE2\x80\x99ll
          try the
            whole
            cause,
              and
           condemn
           you
          to
           death.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99


\xE2\x80\x98You are not attending!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse to Alice severely. \xE2\x80\x98What are you
thinking of?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice very humbly: \xE2\x80\x98you had got to the fifth
bend, I think?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I had NOT!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.

\xE2\x80\x98A knot!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking
anxiously about her. \xE2\x80\x98Oh, do let me help to undo it!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I shall do nothing of the sort,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mouse, getting up and walking
away. \xE2\x80\x98You insult me by talking such nonsense!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I didn\xE2\x80\x99t mean it!\xE2\x80\x99 pleaded poor Alice. \xE2\x80\x98But you\xE2\x80\x99re so easily offended,
you know!\xE2\x80\x99

The Mouse only growled in reply.

\xE2\x80\x98Please come back and finish your story!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice called after it; and the
others all joined in chorus, \xE2\x80\x98Yes, please do!\xE2\x80\x99 but the Mouse only shook
its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.

\xE2\x80\x98What a pity it wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t stay!\xE2\x80\x99 sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite
out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her
daughter \xE2\x80\x98Ah, my dear! Let this be a lesson to you never to lose
YOUR temper!\xE2\x80\x99 \xE2\x80\x98Hold your tongue, Ma!\xE2\x80\x99 said the young Crab, a little
snappishly. \xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re enough to try the patience of an oyster!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice aloud, addressing
nobody in particular. \xE2\x80\x98She\xE2\x80\x99d soon fetch it back!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98And who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?\xE2\x80\x99 said the
Lory.

Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet:
\xE2\x80\x98Dinah\xE2\x80\x99s our cat. And she\xE2\x80\x99s such a capital one for catching mice you
can\xE2\x80\x99t think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why,
she\xE2\x80\x99ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!\xE2\x80\x99

This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party. Some of the
birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very
carefully, remarking, \xE2\x80\x98I really must be getting home; the night-air
doesn\xE2\x80\x99t suit my throat!\xE2\x80\x99 and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to
its children, \xE2\x80\x98Come away, my dears! It\xE2\x80\x99s high time you were all in bed!\xE2\x80\x99
On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.

\xE2\x80\x98I wish I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t mentioned Dinah!\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself in a melancholy
tone. \xE2\x80\x98Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I\xE2\x80\x99m sure she\xE2\x80\x99s the best
cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah! I wonder if I shall ever see you
any more!\xE2\x80\x99 And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very
lonely and low-spirited. In a little while, however, she again heard
a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up
eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming
back to finish his story.




CHAPTER IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill

It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking
anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard
it muttering to itself \xE2\x80\x98The Duchess! The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh
my fur and whiskers! She\xE2\x80\x99ll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are
ferrets! Where CAN I have dropped them, I wonder?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice guessed in a
moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves,
and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were
nowhere to be seen--everything seemed to have changed since her swim in
the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door,
had vanished completely.

Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and
called out to her in an angry tone, \xE2\x80\x98Why, Mary Ann, what ARE you doing
out here? Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan!
Quick, now!\xE2\x80\x99 And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once
in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it
had made.

\xE2\x80\x98He took me for his housemaid,\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself as she ran. \xE2\x80\x98How
surprised he\xE2\x80\x99ll be when he finds out who I am! But I\xE2\x80\x99d better take him
his fan and gloves--that is, if I can find them.\xE2\x80\x99 As she said this, she
came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass
plate with the name \xE2\x80\x98W. RABBIT\xE2\x80\x99 engraved upon it. She went in without
knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the
real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the
fan and gloves.

\xE2\x80\x98How queer it seems,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said to herself, \xE2\x80\x98to be going messages for
a rabbit! I suppose Dinah\xE2\x80\x99ll be sending me on messages next!\xE2\x80\x99 And she
began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x9CMiss Alice! Come
here directly, and get ready for your walk!\xE2\x80\x9D \xE2\x80\x9CComing in a minute,
nurse! But I\xE2\x80\x99ve got to see that the mouse doesn\xE2\x80\x99t get out.\xE2\x80\x9D Only I don\xE2\x80\x99t
think,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice went on, \xE2\x80\x98that they\xE2\x80\x99d let Dinah stop in the house if it
began ordering people about like that!\xE2\x80\x99

By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table
in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs
of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves,
and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little
bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time
with the words \xE2\x80\x98DRINK ME,\xE2\x80\x99 but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it
to her lips. \xE2\x80\x98I know SOMETHING interesting is sure to happen,\xE2\x80\x99 she said
to herself, \xE2\x80\x98whenever I eat or drink anything; so I\xE2\x80\x99ll just see what
this bottle does. I do hope it\xE2\x80\x99ll make me grow large again, for really
I\xE2\x80\x99m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!\xE2\x80\x99

It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had
drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling,
and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put
down the bottle, saying to herself \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s quite enough--I hope I shan\xE2\x80\x99t
grow any more--As it is, I can\xE2\x80\x99t get out at the door--I do wish I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t
drunk quite so much!\xE2\x80\x99

Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing,
and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there
was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with
one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head.
Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out
of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself \xE2\x80\x98Now I
can do no more, whatever happens. What WILL become of me?\xE2\x80\x99

Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect,
and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there
seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room
again, no wonder she felt unhappy.

\xE2\x80\x98It was much pleasanter at home,\xE2\x80\x99 thought poor Alice, \xE2\x80\x98when one wasn\xE2\x80\x99t
always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and
rabbits. I almost wish I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t gone down that rabbit-hole--and yet--and
yet--it\xE2\x80\x99s rather curious, you know, this sort of life! I do wonder what
CAN have happened to me! When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that
kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one!
There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I
grow up, I\xE2\x80\x99ll write one--but I\xE2\x80\x99m grown up now,\xE2\x80\x99 she added in a sorrowful
tone; \xE2\x80\x98at least there\xE2\x80\x99s no room to grow up any more HERE.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But then,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, \xE2\x80\x98shall I NEVER get any older than I am
now? That\xE2\x80\x99ll be a comfort, one way--never to be an old woman--but
then--always to have lessons to learn! Oh, I shouldn\xE2\x80\x99t like THAT!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, you foolish Alice!\xE2\x80\x99 she answered herself. \xE2\x80\x98How can you learn
lessons in here? Why, there\xE2\x80\x99s hardly room for YOU, and no room at all
for any lesson-books!\xE2\x80\x99

And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making
quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard
a voice outside, and stopped to listen.

\xE2\x80\x98Mary Ann! Mary Ann!\xE2\x80\x99 said the voice. \xE2\x80\x98Fetch me my gloves this moment!\xE2\x80\x99
Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs. Alice knew it was
the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the
house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large
as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.

Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as
the door opened inwards, and Alice\xE2\x80\x99s elbow was pressed hard against it,
that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself \xE2\x80\x98Then I\xE2\x80\x99ll
go round and get in at the window.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98THAT you won\xE2\x80\x99t\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied
she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her
hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything,
but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass,
from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a
cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.

Next came an angry voice--the Rabbit\xE2\x80\x99s--\xE2\x80\x98Pat! Pat! Where are you?\xE2\x80\x99 And
then a voice she had never heard before, \xE2\x80\x98Sure then I\xE2\x80\x99m here! Digging
for apples, yer honour!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Digging for apples, indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Rabbit angrily. \xE2\x80\x98Here! Come and
help me out of THIS!\xE2\x80\x99 (Sounds of more broken glass.)

\xE2\x80\x98Now tell me, Pat, what\xE2\x80\x99s that in the window?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Sure, it\xE2\x80\x99s an arm, yer honour!\xE2\x80\x99 (He pronounced it \xE2\x80\x98arrum.\xE2\x80\x99)

\xE2\x80\x98An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole
window!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Sure, it does, yer honour: but it\xE2\x80\x99s an arm for all that.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, it\xE2\x80\x99s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!\xE2\x80\x99

There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers
now and then; such as, \xE2\x80\x98Sure, I don\xE2\x80\x99t like it, yer honour, at all, at
all!\xE2\x80\x99 \xE2\x80\x98Do as I tell you, you coward!\xE2\x80\x99 and at last she spread out her
hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were
TWO little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. \xE2\x80\x98What a number of
cucumber-frames there must be!\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I wonder what they\xE2\x80\x99ll do
next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they COULD! I\xE2\x80\x99m
sure I don\xE2\x80\x99t want to stay in here any longer!\xE2\x80\x99

She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a
rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices
all talking together: she made out the words: \xE2\x80\x98Where\xE2\x80\x99s the other
ladder?--Why, I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t to bring but one; Bill\xE2\x80\x99s got the other--Bill!
fetch it here, lad!--Here, put \xE2\x80\x98em up at this corner--No, tie \xE2\x80\x98em
together first--they don\xE2\x80\x99t reach half high enough yet--Oh! they\xE2\x80\x99ll
do well enough; don\xE2\x80\x99t be particular--Here, Bill! catch hold of this
rope--Will the roof bear?--Mind that loose slate--Oh, it\xE2\x80\x99s coming
down! Heads below!\xE2\x80\x99 (a loud crash)--\xE2\x80\x98Now, who did that?--It was Bill, I
fancy--Who\xE2\x80\x99s to go down the chimney?--Nay, I shan\xE2\x80\x99t! YOU do it!--That I
won\xE2\x80\x99t, then!--Bill\xE2\x80\x99s to go down--Here, Bill! the master says you\xE2\x80\x99re to
go down the chimney!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh! So Bill\xE2\x80\x99s got to come down the chimney, has he?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice to
herself. \xE2\x80\x98Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t be in
Bill\xE2\x80\x99s place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but
I THINK I can kick a little!\xE2\x80\x99

She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited
till she heard a little animal (she couldn\xE2\x80\x99t guess of what sort it was)
scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then,
saying to herself \xE2\x80\x98This is Bill,\xE2\x80\x99 she gave one sharp kick, and waited to
see what would happen next.

The first thing she heard was a general chorus of \xE2\x80\x98There goes Bill!\xE2\x80\x99
then the Rabbit\xE2\x80\x99s voice along--\xE2\x80\x98Catch him, you by the hedge!\xE2\x80\x99 then
silence, and then another confusion of voices--\xE2\x80\x98Hold up his head--Brandy
now--Don\xE2\x80\x99t choke him--How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell
us all about it!\xE2\x80\x99

Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, [\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s Bill,\xE2\x80\x99 thought
Alice,) \xE2\x80\x98Well, I hardly know--No more, thank ye; I\xE2\x80\x99m better now--but I\xE2\x80\x99m
a deal too flustered to tell you--all I know is, something comes at me
like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98So you did, old fellow!\xE2\x80\x99 said the others.

\xE2\x80\x98We must burn the house down!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Rabbit\xE2\x80\x99s voice; and Alice called
out as loud as she could, \xE2\x80\x98If you do. I\xE2\x80\x99ll set Dinah at you!\xE2\x80\x99

There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, \xE2\x80\x98I
wonder what they WILL do next! If they had any sense, they\xE2\x80\x99d take the
roof off.\xE2\x80\x99 After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and
Alice heard the Rabbit say, \xE2\x80\x98A barrowful will do, to begin with.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98A barrowful of WHAT?\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt,
for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the
window, and some of them hit her in the face. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ll put a stop to this,\xE2\x80\x99
she said to herself, and shouted out, \xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99d better not do that again!\xE2\x80\x99
which produced another dead silence.

Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into
little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her
head. \xE2\x80\x98If I eat one of these cakes,\xE2\x80\x99 she thought, \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s sure to make
SOME change in my size; and as it can\xE2\x80\x99t possibly make me larger, it must
make me smaller, I suppose.\xE2\x80\x99

So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she
began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through
the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little
animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was
in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it
something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she
appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself
safe in a thick wood.

\xE2\x80\x98The first thing I\xE2\x80\x99ve got to do,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice to herself, as she wandered
about in the wood, \xE2\x80\x98is to grow to my right size again; and the second
thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be
the best plan.\xE2\x80\x99

It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply
arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea
how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among
the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a
great hurry.

An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and
feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her. \xE2\x80\x98Poor little thing!\xE2\x80\x99
said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but
she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be
hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of
all her coaxing.

Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and
held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off
all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick,
and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle,
to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the
other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head
over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice, thinking it was
very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every
moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then
the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very
little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely
all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with
its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.

This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she
set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and
till the puppy\xE2\x80\x99s bark sounded quite faint in the distance.

\xE2\x80\x98And yet what a dear little puppy it was!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, as she leant
against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the
leaves: \xE2\x80\x98I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if--if I\xE2\x80\x99d
only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I\xE2\x80\x99d nearly forgotten that
I\xE2\x80\x99ve got to grow up again! Let me see--how IS it to be managed? I
suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great
question is, what?\xE2\x80\x99

The great question certainly was, what? Alice looked all round her at
the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that
looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.
There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as
herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and
behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what
was on the top of it.

She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the
mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar,
that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long
hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.




CHAPTER V. Advice from a Caterpillar

The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence:
at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed
her in a languid, sleepy voice.

\xE2\x80\x98Who are YOU?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied,
rather shyly, \xE2\x80\x98I--I hardly know, sir, just at present--at least I know
who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been
changed several times since then.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What do you mean by that?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar sternly. \xE2\x80\x98Explain
yourself!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I can\xE2\x80\x99t explain MYSELF, I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid, sir\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98because I\xE2\x80\x99m not
myself, you see.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t see,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid I can\xE2\x80\x99t put it more clearly,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied very politely,
\xE2\x80\x98for I can\xE2\x80\x99t understand it myself to begin with; and being so many
different sizes in a day is very confusing.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It isn\xE2\x80\x99t,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, perhaps you haven\xE2\x80\x99t found it so yet,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98but when you
have to turn into a chrysalis--you will some day, you know--and then
after that into a butterfly, I should think you\xE2\x80\x99ll feel it a little
queer, won\xE2\x80\x99t you?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Not a bit,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98all I know
is, it would feel very queer to ME.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar contemptuously. \xE2\x80\x98Who are YOU?\xE2\x80\x99

Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation.
Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar\xE2\x80\x99s making such VERY
short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, \xE2\x80\x98I think,
you ought to tell me who YOU are, first.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Why?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any
good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a VERY unpleasant
state of mind, she turned away.

\xE2\x80\x98Come back!\xE2\x80\x99 the Caterpillar called after her. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve something important
to say!\xE2\x80\x99

This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.

\xE2\x80\x98Keep your temper,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Is that all?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she
could.

\xE2\x80\x98No,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and
perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing. For some
minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its
arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, \xE2\x80\x98So you think
you\xE2\x80\x99re changed, do you?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid I am, sir,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98I can\xE2\x80\x99t remember things as I
used--and I don\xE2\x80\x99t keep the same size for ten minutes together!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Can\xE2\x80\x99t remember WHAT things?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I\xE2\x80\x99ve tried to say \xE2\x80\x9CHOW DOTH THE LITTLE BUSY BEE,\xE2\x80\x9D but it all came
different!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.

\xE2\x80\x98Repeat, \xE2\x80\x9CYOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

Alice folded her hands, and began:--

   \xE2\x80\x98You are old, Father William,\xE2\x80\x99 the young man said,
    \xE2\x80\x98And your hair has become very white;
   And yet you incessantly stand on your head--
    Do you think, at your age, it is right?\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98In my youth,\xE2\x80\x99 Father William replied to his son,
    \xE2\x80\x98I feared it might injure the brain;
   But, now that I\xE2\x80\x99m perfectly sure I have none,
    Why, I do it again and again.\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98You are old,\xE2\x80\x99 said the youth, \xE2\x80\x98as I mentioned before,
    And have grown most uncommonly fat;
   Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door--
    Pray, what is the reason of that?\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98In my youth,\xE2\x80\x99 said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
    \xE2\x80\x98I kept all my limbs very supple
   By the use of this ointment--one shilling the box--
    Allow me to sell you a couple?\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98You are old,\xE2\x80\x99 said the youth, \xE2\x80\x98and your jaws are too weak
    For anything tougher than suet;
   Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak--
    Pray how did you manage to do it?\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98In my youth,\xE2\x80\x99 said his father, \xE2\x80\x98I took to the law,
    And argued each case with my wife;
   And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
    Has lasted the rest of my life.\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98You are old,\xE2\x80\x99 said the youth, \xE2\x80\x98one would hardly suppose
    That your eye was as steady as ever;
   Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose--
    What made you so awfully clever?\xE2\x80\x99

   \xE2\x80\x98I have answered three questions, and that is enough,\xE2\x80\x99
    Said his father; \xE2\x80\x98don\xE2\x80\x99t give yourself airs!
   Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
    Be off, or I\xE2\x80\x99ll kick you down stairs!\xE2\x80\x99


\xE2\x80\x98That is not said right,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Not QUITE right, I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, timidly; \xE2\x80\x98some of the words
have got altered.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It is wrong from beginning to end,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar decidedly, and
there was silence for some minutes.

The Caterpillar was the first to speak.

\xE2\x80\x98What size do you want to be?\xE2\x80\x99 it asked.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, I\xE2\x80\x99m not particular as to size,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice hastily replied; \xE2\x80\x98only one
doesn\xE2\x80\x99t like changing so often, you know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I DON\xE2\x80\x99T know,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life
before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.

\xE2\x80\x98Are you content now?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I should like to be a LITTLE larger, sir, if you wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t mind,\xE2\x80\x99
said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98three inches is such a wretched height to be.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It is a very good height indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing
itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).

\xE2\x80\x98But I\xE2\x80\x99m not used to it!\xE2\x80\x99 pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And
she thought of herself, \xE2\x80\x98I wish the creatures wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t be so easily
offended!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99ll get used to it in time,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar; and it put the
hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.

This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again. In
a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth
and yawned once or twice, and shook itself. Then it got down off the
mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went,
\xE2\x80\x98One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you
grow shorter.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98One side of WHAT? The other side of WHAT?\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice to herself.

\xE2\x80\x98Of the mushroom,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it
aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.

Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying
to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly
round, she found this a very difficult question. However, at last she
stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit
of the edge with each hand.

\xE2\x80\x98And now which is which?\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself, and nibbled a little of
the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent
blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!

She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt
that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she
set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed
so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her
mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the
lefthand bit.


  *    *    *    *    *    *    *

    *    *    *    *    *    *

  *    *    *    *    *    *    *

\xE2\x80\x98Come, my head\xE2\x80\x99s free at last!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice in a tone of delight, which
changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders
were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was
an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a
sea of green leaves that lay far below her.

\xE2\x80\x98What CAN all that green stuff be?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98And where HAVE my
shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can\xE2\x80\x99t see you?\xE2\x80\x99
She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow,
except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.

As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she
tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her
neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had
just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going
to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops
of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made
her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and
was beating her violently with its wings.

\xE2\x80\x98Serpent!\xE2\x80\x99 screamed the Pigeon.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m NOT a serpent!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice indignantly. \xE2\x80\x98Let me alone!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Serpent, I say again!\xE2\x80\x99 repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone,
and added with a kind of sob, \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve tried every way, and nothing seems
to suit them!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I haven\xE2\x80\x99t the least idea what you\xE2\x80\x99re talking about,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve tried the roots of trees, and I\xE2\x80\x99ve tried banks, and I\xE2\x80\x99ve tried
hedges,\xE2\x80\x99 the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; \xE2\x80\x98but those
serpents! There\xE2\x80\x99s no pleasing them!\xE2\x80\x99

Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in
saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.

\xE2\x80\x98As if it wasn\xE2\x80\x99t trouble enough hatching the eggs,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Pigeon;
\xE2\x80\x98but I must be on the look-out for serpents night and day! Why, I
haven\xE2\x80\x99t had a wink of sleep these three weeks!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m very sorry you\xE2\x80\x99ve been annoyed,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, who was beginning to
see its meaning.

\xE2\x80\x98And just as I\xE2\x80\x99d taken the highest tree in the wood,\xE2\x80\x99 continued the
Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, \xE2\x80\x98and just as I was thinking I
should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from
the sky! Ugh, Serpent!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But I\xE2\x80\x99m NOT a serpent, I tell you!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m a--I\xE2\x80\x99m a--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well! WHAT are you?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Pigeon. \xE2\x80\x98I can see you\xE2\x80\x99re trying to
invent something!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I--I\xE2\x80\x99m a little girl,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered
the number of changes she had gone through that day.

\xE2\x80\x98A likely story indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest
contempt. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve seen a good many little girls in my time, but never ONE
with such a neck as that! No, no! You\xE2\x80\x99re a serpent; and there\xE2\x80\x99s no use
denying it. I suppose you\xE2\x80\x99ll be telling me next that you never tasted an
egg!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I HAVE tasted eggs, certainly,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, who was a very truthful
child; \xE2\x80\x98but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you
know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t believe it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Pigeon; \xE2\x80\x98but if they do, why then they\xE2\x80\x99re
a kind of serpent, that\xE2\x80\x99s all I can say.\xE2\x80\x99

This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a
minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, \xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re
looking for eggs, I know THAT well enough; and what does it matter to me
whether you\xE2\x80\x99re a little girl or a serpent?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It matters a good deal to ME,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice hastily; \xE2\x80\x98but I\xE2\x80\x99m not looking
for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn\xE2\x80\x99t want YOURS: I don\xE2\x80\x99t
like them raw.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, be off, then!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled
down again into its nest. Alice crouched down among the trees as well as
she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and
every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while she
remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and
she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the
other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had
succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.

It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it
felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes,
and began talking to herself, as usual. \xE2\x80\x98Come, there\xE2\x80\x99s half my plan done
now! How puzzling all these changes are! I\xE2\x80\x99m never sure what I\xE2\x80\x99m going
to be, from one minute to another! However, I\xE2\x80\x99ve got back to my right
size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden--how IS that
to be done, I wonder?\xE2\x80\x99 As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open
place, with a little house in it about four feet high. \xE2\x80\x98Whoever lives
there,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99ll never do to come upon them THIS size: why,
I should frighten them out of their wits!\xE2\x80\x99 So she began nibbling at the
righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she
had brought herself down to nine inches high.




CHAPTER VI. Pig and Pepper

For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what
to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the
wood--(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery:
otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a
fish)--and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened
by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a
frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all
over their heads. She felt very curious to know what it was all about,
and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.

The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter,
nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other,
saying, in a solemn tone, \xE2\x80\x98For the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen
to play croquet.\xE2\x80\x99 The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone,
only changing the order of the words a little, \xE2\x80\x98From the Queen. An
invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.\xE2\x80\x99

Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.

Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the
wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the
Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the
door, staring stupidly up into the sky.

Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.

\xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s no sort of use in knocking,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Footman, \xE2\x80\x98and that for
two reasons. First, because I\xE2\x80\x99m on the same side of the door as you
are; secondly, because they\xE2\x80\x99re making such a noise inside, no one could
possibly hear you.\xE2\x80\x99 And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise
going on within--a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then
a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.

\xE2\x80\x98Please, then,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98how am I to get in?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98There might be some sense in your knocking,\xE2\x80\x99 the Footman went on
without attending to her, \xE2\x80\x98if we had the door between us. For instance,
if you were INSIDE, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.\xE2\x80\x99
He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this
Alice thought decidedly uncivil. \xE2\x80\x98But perhaps he can\xE2\x80\x99t help it,\xE2\x80\x99 she
said to herself; \xE2\x80\x98his eyes are so VERY nearly at the top of his head.
But at any rate he might answer questions.--How am I to get in?\xE2\x80\x99 she
repeated, aloud.

\xE2\x80\x98I shall sit here,\xE2\x80\x99 the Footman remarked, \xE2\x80\x98till tomorrow--\xE2\x80\x99

At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came
skimming out, straight at the Footman\xE2\x80\x99s head: it just grazed his nose,
and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.

\xE2\x80\x98--or next day, maybe,\xE2\x80\x99 the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly
as if nothing had happened.

\xE2\x80\x98How am I to get in?\xE2\x80\x99 asked Alice again, in a louder tone.

\xE2\x80\x98ARE you to get in at all?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Footman. \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s the first
question, you know.\xE2\x80\x99

It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so. \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s really
dreadful,\xE2\x80\x99 she muttered to herself, \xE2\x80\x98the way all the creatures argue.
It\xE2\x80\x99s enough to drive one crazy!\xE2\x80\x99

The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his
remark, with variations. \xE2\x80\x98I shall sit here,\xE2\x80\x99 he said, \xE2\x80\x98on and off, for
days and days.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But what am I to do?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Anything you like,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Footman, and began whistling.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, there\xE2\x80\x99s no use in talking to him,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice desperately: \xE2\x80\x98he\xE2\x80\x99s
perfectly idiotic!\xE2\x80\x99 And she opened the door and went in.

The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from
one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in
the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring
a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.

\xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s certainly too much pepper in that soup!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said to herself,
as well as she could for sneezing.

There was certainly too much of it in the air. Even the Duchess
sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling
alternately without a moment\xE2\x80\x99s pause. The only things in the kitchen
that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on
the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.

\xE2\x80\x98Please would you tell me,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, a little timidly, for she was
not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, \xE2\x80\x98why
your cat grins like that?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s a Cheshire cat,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess, \xE2\x80\x98and that\xE2\x80\x99s why. Pig!\xE2\x80\x99

She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite
jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby,
and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:--

\xE2\x80\x98I didn\xE2\x80\x99t know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn\xE2\x80\x99t know
that cats COULD grin.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98They all can,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess; \xE2\x80\x98and most of \xE2\x80\x98em do.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t know of any that do,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said very politely, feeling quite
pleased to have got into a conversation.

\xE2\x80\x98You don\xE2\x80\x99t know much,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess; \xE2\x80\x98and that\xE2\x80\x99s a fact.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would
be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation. While she
was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the
fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at
the Duchess and the baby--the fire-irons came first; then followed a
shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes. The Duchess took no notice of
them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already,
that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, PLEASE mind what you\xE2\x80\x99re doing!\xE2\x80\x99 cried Alice, jumping up and down in
an agony of terror. \xE2\x80\x98Oh, there goes his PRECIOUS nose\xE2\x80\x99; as an unusually
large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.

\xE2\x80\x98If everybody minded their own business,\xE2\x80\x99 the Duchess said in a hoarse
growl, \xE2\x80\x98the world would go round a deal faster than it does.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Which would NOT be an advantage,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, who felt very glad to get
an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge. \xE2\x80\x98Just think of
what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes
twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Talking of axes,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess, \xE2\x80\x98chop off her head!\xE2\x80\x99

Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take
the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to
be listening, so she went on again: \xE2\x80\x98Twenty-four hours, I THINK; or is
it twelve? I--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, don\xE2\x80\x99t bother ME,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess; \xE2\x80\x98I never could abide figures!\xE2\x80\x99
And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of
lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of
every line:

   \xE2\x80\x98Speak roughly to your little boy,
    And beat him when he sneezes:
   He only does it to annoy,
    Because he knows it teases.\xE2\x80\x99

         CHORUS.

 (In which the cook and the baby joined):--

       \xE2\x80\x98Wow! wow! wow!\xE2\x80\x99

While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing
the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so,
that Alice could hardly hear the words:--

   \xE2\x80\x98I speak severely to my boy,
    I beat him when he sneezes;
   For he can thoroughly enjoy
    The pepper when he pleases!\xE2\x80\x99

         CHORUS.

       \xE2\x80\x98Wow! wow! wow!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!\xE2\x80\x99 the Duchess said to Alice,
flinging the baby at her as she spoke. \xE2\x80\x98I must go and get ready to play
croquet with the Queen,\xE2\x80\x99 and she hurried out of the room. The cook threw
a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.

Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped
little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, \xE2\x80\x98just
like a star-fish,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. The poor little thing was snorting
like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and
straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute
or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.

As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to
twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right
ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried
it out into the open air. \xE2\x80\x98IF I don\xE2\x80\x99t take this child away with me,\xE2\x80\x99
thought Alice, \xE2\x80\x98they\xE2\x80\x99re sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t it be
murder to leave it behind?\xE2\x80\x99 She said the last words out loud, and the
little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).
\xE2\x80\x98Don\xE2\x80\x99t grunt,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98that\xE2\x80\x99s not at all a proper way of expressing
yourself.\xE2\x80\x99

The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to
see what was the matter with it. There could be no doubt that it had
a VERY turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its
eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not
like the look of the thing at all. \xE2\x80\x98But perhaps it was only sobbing,\xE2\x80\x99
she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any
tears.

No, there were no tears. \xE2\x80\x98If you\xE2\x80\x99re going to turn into a pig, my dear,\xE2\x80\x99
said Alice, seriously, \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ll have nothing more to do with you. Mind
now!\xE2\x80\x99 The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible
to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.

Alice was just beginning to think to herself, \xE2\x80\x98Now, what am I to do with
this creature when I get it home?\xE2\x80\x99 when it grunted again, so violently,
that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time there could
be NO mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she
felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.

So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see
it trot away quietly into the wood. \xE2\x80\x98If it had grown up,\xE2\x80\x99 she said
to herself, \xE2\x80\x98it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes
rather a handsome pig, I think.\xE2\x80\x99 And she began thinking over other
children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying
to herself, \xE2\x80\x98if one only knew the right way to change them--\xE2\x80\x99 when she
was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a
tree a few yards off.

The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice. It looked good-natured, she
thought: still it had VERY long claws and a great many teeth, so she
felt that it ought to be treated with respect.

\xE2\x80\x98Cheshire Puss,\xE2\x80\x99 she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know
whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.
\xE2\x80\x98Come, it\xE2\x80\x99s pleased so far,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, and she went on. \xE2\x80\x98Would you
tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98That depends a good deal on where you want to get to,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat.

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t much care where--\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Then it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t matter which way you go,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat.

\xE2\x80\x98--so long as I get SOMEWHERE,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice added as an explanation.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, you\xE2\x80\x99re sure to do that,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, \xE2\x80\x98if you only walk long
enough.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
\xE2\x80\x98What sort of people live about here?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98In THAT direction,\xE2\x80\x99 the Cat said, waving its right paw round, \xE2\x80\x98lives
a Hatter: and in THAT direction,\xE2\x80\x99 waving the other paw, \xE2\x80\x98lives a March
Hare. Visit either you like: they\xE2\x80\x99re both mad.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But I don\xE2\x80\x99t want to go among mad people,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice remarked.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, you can\xE2\x80\x99t help that,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat: \xE2\x80\x98we\xE2\x80\x99re all mad here. I\xE2\x80\x99m mad.
You\xE2\x80\x99re mad.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98How do you know I\xE2\x80\x99m mad?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98You must be,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, \xE2\x80\x98or you wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t have come here.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice didn\xE2\x80\x99t think that proved it at all; however, she went on \xE2\x80\x98And how
do you know that you\xE2\x80\x99re mad?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98To begin with,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, \xE2\x80\x98a dog\xE2\x80\x99s not mad. You grant that?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I suppose so,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, then,\xE2\x80\x99 the Cat went on, \xE2\x80\x98you see, a dog growls when it\xE2\x80\x99s angry,
and wags its tail when it\xE2\x80\x99s pleased. Now I growl when I\xE2\x80\x99m pleased, and
wag my tail when I\xE2\x80\x99m angry. Therefore I\xE2\x80\x99m mad.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I call it purring, not growling,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Call it what you like,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat. \xE2\x80\x98Do you play croquet with the
Queen to-day?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I should like it very much,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98but I haven\xE2\x80\x99t been invited
yet.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99ll see me there,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, and vanished.

Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer
things happening. While she was looking at the place where it had been,
it suddenly appeared again.

\xE2\x80\x98By-the-bye, what became of the baby?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99d nearly
forgotten to ask.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It turned into a pig,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back
in a natural way.

\xE2\x80\x98I thought it would,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, and vanished again.

Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not
appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in
which the March Hare was said to live. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve seen hatters before,\xE2\x80\x99 she
said to herself; \xE2\x80\x98the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and
perhaps as this is May it won\xE2\x80\x99t be raving mad--at least not so mad as
it was in March.\xE2\x80\x99 As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat
again, sitting on a branch of a tree.

\xE2\x80\x98Did you say pig, or fig?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat.

\xE2\x80\x98I said pig,\xE2\x80\x99 replied Alice; \xE2\x80\x98and I wish you wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t keep appearing and
vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98All right,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly,
beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which
remained some time after the rest of it had gone.

\xE2\x80\x98Well! I\xE2\x80\x99ve often seen a cat without a grin,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice; \xE2\x80\x98but a grin
without a cat! It\xE2\x80\x99s the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!\xE2\x80\x99

She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house
of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the
chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It
was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had
nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to
about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly,
saying to herself \xE2\x80\x98Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost
wish I\xE2\x80\x99d gone to see the Hatter instead!\xE2\x80\x99




CHAPTER VII. A Mad Tea-Party

There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the
March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting
between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a
cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head. \xE2\x80\x98Very
uncomfortable for the Dormouse,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice; \xE2\x80\x98only, as it\xE2\x80\x99s asleep, I
suppose it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t mind.\xE2\x80\x99

The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at
one corner of it: \xE2\x80\x98No room! No room!\xE2\x80\x99 they cried out when they saw Alice
coming. \xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s PLENTY of room!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice indignantly, and she sat
down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.

\xE2\x80\x98Have some wine,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.

Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea.
\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t see any wine,\xE2\x80\x99 she remarked.

\xE2\x80\x98There isn\xE2\x80\x99t any,\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98Then it wasn\xE2\x80\x99t very civil of you to offer it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice angrily.

\xE2\x80\x98It wasn\xE2\x80\x99t very civil of you to sit down without being invited,\xE2\x80\x99 said
the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98I didn\xE2\x80\x99t know it was YOUR table,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s laid for a great
many more than three.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Your hair wants cutting,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice
for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.

\xE2\x80\x98You should learn not to make personal remarks,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said with some
severity; \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s very rude.\xE2\x80\x99

The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he SAID
was, \xE2\x80\x98Why is a raven like a writing-desk?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Come, we shall have some fun now!\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m glad they\xE2\x80\x99ve
begun asking riddles.--I believe I can guess that,\xE2\x80\x99 she added aloud.

\xE2\x80\x98Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?\xE2\x80\x99 said the
March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98Exactly so,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Then you should say what you mean,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare went on.

\xE2\x80\x98I do,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice hastily replied; \xE2\x80\x98at least--at least I mean what I
say--that\xE2\x80\x99s the same thing, you know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Not the same thing a bit!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter. \xE2\x80\x98You might just as well say
that \xE2\x80\x9CI see what I eat\xE2\x80\x9D is the same thing as \xE2\x80\x9CI eat what I see\xE2\x80\x9D!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You might just as well say,\xE2\x80\x99 added the March Hare, \xE2\x80\x98that \xE2\x80\x9CI like what I
get\xE2\x80\x9D is the same thing as \xE2\x80\x9CI get what I like\xE2\x80\x9D!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You might just as well say,\xE2\x80\x99 added the Dormouse, who seemed to be
talking in his sleep, \xE2\x80\x98that \xE2\x80\x9CI breathe when I sleep\xE2\x80\x9D is the same thing
as \xE2\x80\x9CI sleep when I breathe\xE2\x80\x9D!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It IS the same thing with you,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter, and here the
conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice
thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks,
which wasn\xE2\x80\x99t much.

The Hatter was the first to break the silence. \xE2\x80\x98What day of the month
is it?\xE2\x80\x99 he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his
pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then,
and holding it to his ear.

Alice considered a little, and then said \xE2\x80\x98The fourth.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Two days wrong!\xE2\x80\x99 sighed the Hatter. \xE2\x80\x98I told you butter wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t suit
the works!\xE2\x80\x99 he added looking angrily at the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98It was the BEST butter,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare meekly replied.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter grumbled:
\xE2\x80\x98you shouldn\xE2\x80\x99t have put it in with the bread-knife.\xE2\x80\x99

The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped
it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of
nothing better to say than his first remark, \xE2\x80\x98It was the BEST butter,
you know.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. \xE2\x80\x98What a
funny watch!\xE2\x80\x99 she remarked. \xE2\x80\x98It tells the day of the month, and doesn\xE2\x80\x99t
tell what o\xE2\x80\x99clock it is!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Why should it?\xE2\x80\x99 muttered the Hatter. \xE2\x80\x98Does YOUR watch tell you what
year it is?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Of course not,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied very readily: \xE2\x80\x98but that\xE2\x80\x99s because it
stays the same year for such a long time together.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Which is just the case with MINE,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter\xE2\x80\x99s remark seemed to have no
sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t quite
understand you,\xE2\x80\x99 she said, as politely as she could.

\xE2\x80\x98The Dormouse is asleep again,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter, and he poured a little
hot tea upon its nose.

The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its
eyes, \xE2\x80\x98Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Have you guessed the riddle yet?\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter said, turning to Alice
again.

\xE2\x80\x98No, I give it up,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied: \xE2\x80\x98what\xE2\x80\x99s the answer?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I haven\xE2\x80\x99t the slightest idea,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

\xE2\x80\x98Nor I,\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

Alice sighed wearily. \xE2\x80\x98I think you might do something better with the
time,\xE2\x80\x99 she said, \xE2\x80\x98than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98If you knew Time as well as I do,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter, \xE2\x80\x98you wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t talk
about wasting IT. It\xE2\x80\x99s HIM.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t know what you mean,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course you don\xE2\x80\x99t!\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously.
\xE2\x80\x98I dare say you never even spoke to Time!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Perhaps not,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice cautiously replied: \xE2\x80\x98but I know I have to beat time
when I learn music.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Ah! that accounts for it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter. \xE2\x80\x98He won\xE2\x80\x99t stand beating.
Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he\xE2\x80\x99d do almost anything
you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o\xE2\x80\x99clock in
the morning, just time to begin lessons: you\xE2\x80\x99d only have to whisper a
hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one,
time for dinner!\xE2\x80\x99

[\xE2\x80\x98I only wish it was,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)

\xE2\x80\x98That would be grand, certainly,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice thoughtfully: \xE2\x80\x98but then--I
shouldn\xE2\x80\x99t be hungry for it, you know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Not at first, perhaps,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter: \xE2\x80\x98but you could keep it to
half-past one as long as you liked.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Is that the way YOU manage?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice asked.

The Hatter shook his head mournfully. \xE2\x80\x98Not I!\xE2\x80\x99 he replied. \xE2\x80\x98We
quarrelled last March--just before HE went mad, you know--\xE2\x80\x99 (pointing
with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) \xE2\x80\x98--it was at the great concert
given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing

     \xE2\x80\x9CTwinkle, twinkle, little bat!
     How I wonder what you\xE2\x80\x99re at!\xE2\x80\x9D

You know the song, perhaps?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve heard something like it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98It goes on, you know,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter continued, \xE2\x80\x98in this way:--

     \xE2\x80\x9CUp above the world you fly,
     Like a tea-tray in the sky.
         Twinkle, twinkle--\xE2\x80\x9C\xE2\x80\x99

Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep \xE2\x80\x98Twinkle,
twinkle, twinkle, twinkle--\xE2\x80\x99 and went on so long that they had to pinch
it to make it stop.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I\xE2\x80\x99d hardly finished the first verse,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter, \xE2\x80\x98when the
Queen jumped up and bawled out, \xE2\x80\x9CHe\xE2\x80\x99s murdering the time! Off with his
head!\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98How dreadfully savage!\xE2\x80\x99 exclaimed Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98And ever since that,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, \xE2\x80\x98he won\xE2\x80\x99t
do a thing I ask! It\xE2\x80\x99s always six o\xE2\x80\x99clock now.\xE2\x80\x99

A bright idea came into Alice\xE2\x80\x99s head. \xE2\x80\x98Is that the reason so many
tea-things are put out here?\xE2\x80\x99 she asked.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, that\xE2\x80\x99s it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter with a sigh: \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s always tea-time,
and we\xE2\x80\x99ve no time to wash the things between whiles.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Then you keep moving round, I suppose?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Exactly so,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter: \xE2\x80\x98as the things get used up.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But what happens when you come to the beginning again?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice ventured
to ask.

\xE2\x80\x98Suppose we change the subject,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare interrupted, yawning.
\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m afraid I don\xE2\x80\x99t know one,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, rather alarmed at the
proposal.

\xE2\x80\x98Then the Dormouse shall!\xE2\x80\x99 they both cried. \xE2\x80\x98Wake up, Dormouse!\xE2\x80\x99 And
they pinched it on both sides at once.

The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. \xE2\x80\x98I wasn\xE2\x80\x99t asleep,\xE2\x80\x99 he said in a
hoarse, feeble voice: \xE2\x80\x98I heard every word you fellows were saying.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Tell us a story!\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, please do!\xE2\x80\x99 pleaded Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98And be quick about it,\xE2\x80\x99 added the Hatter, \xE2\x80\x98or you\xE2\x80\x99ll be asleep again
before it\xE2\x80\x99s done.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Once upon a time there were three little sisters,\xE2\x80\x99 the Dormouse began
in a great hurry; \xE2\x80\x98and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and
they lived at the bottom of a well--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What did they live on?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, who always took a great interest in
questions of eating and drinking.

\xE2\x80\x98They lived on treacle,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or
two.

\xE2\x80\x98They couldn\xE2\x80\x99t have done that, you know,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice gently remarked; \xE2\x80\x98they\xE2\x80\x99d
have been ill.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98So they were,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse; \xE2\x80\x98VERY ill.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of
living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: \xE2\x80\x98But
why did they live at the bottom of a well?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Take some more tea,\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve had nothing yet,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied in an offended tone, \xE2\x80\x98so I can\xE2\x80\x99t
take more.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You mean you can\xE2\x80\x99t take LESS,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter: \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s very easy to take
MORE than nothing.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Nobody asked YOUR opinion,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Who\xE2\x80\x99s making personal remarks now?\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter asked triumphantly.

Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself
to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and
repeated her question. \xE2\x80\x98Why did they live at the bottom of a well?\xE2\x80\x99

The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then
said, \xE2\x80\x98It was a treacle-well.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s no such thing!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice was beginning very angrily, but the
Hatter and the March Hare went \xE2\x80\x98Sh! sh!\xE2\x80\x99 and the Dormouse sulkily
remarked, \xE2\x80\x98If you can\xE2\x80\x99t be civil, you\xE2\x80\x99d better finish the story for
yourself.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98No, please go on!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said very humbly; \xE2\x80\x98I won\xE2\x80\x99t interrupt again. I
dare say there may be ONE.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98One, indeed!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse indignantly. However, he consented to
go on. \xE2\x80\x98And so these three little sisters--they were learning to draw,
you know--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What did they draw?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.

\xE2\x80\x98Treacle,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.

\xE2\x80\x98I want a clean cup,\xE2\x80\x99 interrupted the Hatter: \xE2\x80\x98let\xE2\x80\x99s all move one place
on.\xE2\x80\x99

He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare
moved into the Dormouse\xE2\x80\x99s place, and Alice rather unwillingly took
the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any
advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than
before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.

Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very
cautiously: \xE2\x80\x98But I don\xE2\x80\x99t understand. Where did they draw the treacle
from?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You can draw water out of a water-well,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter; \xE2\x80\x98so I should
think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well--eh, stupid?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But they were IN the well,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to
notice this last remark.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course they were\xE2\x80\x99, said the Dormouse; \xE2\x80\x98--well in.\xE2\x80\x99

This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for
some time without interrupting it.

\xE2\x80\x98They were learning to draw,\xE2\x80\x99 the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing
its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; \xE2\x80\x98and they drew all manner of
things--everything that begins with an M--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Why with an M?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Why not?\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

Alice was silent.

The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into
a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with
a little shriek, and went on: \xE2\x80\x98--that begins with an M, such as
mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness--you know you say
things are \xE2\x80\x9Cmuch of a muchness\xE2\x80\x9D--did you ever see such a thing as a
drawing of a muchness?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Really, now you ask me,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, very much confused, \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t
think--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Then you shouldn\xE2\x80\x99t talk,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in
great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and
neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she
looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her:
the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into
the teapot.

\xE2\x80\x98At any rate I\xE2\x80\x99ll never go THERE again!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice as she picked her
