way through the wood. \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all
my life!\xE2\x80\x99

Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door
leading right into it. \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s very curious!\xE2\x80\x99 she thought. \xE2\x80\x98But
everything\xE2\x80\x99s curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.\xE2\x80\x99 And in
she went.

Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little
glass table. \xE2\x80\x98Now, I\xE2\x80\x99ll manage better this time,\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself,
and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that
led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she
had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high:
then she walked down the little passage: and THEN--she found herself at
last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool
fountains.




CHAPTER VIII. The Queen\xE2\x80\x99s Croquet-Ground

A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses
growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily
painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went
nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of
them say, \xE2\x80\x98Look out now, Five! Don\xE2\x80\x99t go splashing paint over me like
that!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I couldn\xE2\x80\x99t help it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Five, in a sulky tone; \xE2\x80\x98Seven jogged my
elbow.\xE2\x80\x99

On which Seven looked up and said, \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s right, Five! Always lay the
blame on others!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98YOU\xE2\x80\x99D better not talk!\xE2\x80\x99 said Five. \xE2\x80\x98I heard the Queen say only
yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What for?\xE2\x80\x99 said the one who had spoken first.

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s none of YOUR business, Two!\xE2\x80\x99 said Seven.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, it IS his business!\xE2\x80\x99 said Five, \xE2\x80\x98and I\xE2\x80\x99ll tell him--it was for
bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.\xE2\x80\x99

Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun \xE2\x80\x98Well, of all the unjust
things--\xE2\x80\x99 when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching
them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and
all of them bowed low.

\xE2\x80\x98Would you tell me,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, a little timidly, \xE2\x80\x98why you are painting
those roses?\xE2\x80\x99

Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low
voice, \xE2\x80\x98Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a
RED rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen
was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know.
So you see, Miss, we\xE2\x80\x99re doing our best, afore she comes, to--\xE2\x80\x99 At this
moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called
out \xE2\x80\x98The Queen! The Queen!\xE2\x80\x99 and the three gardeners instantly threw
themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps,
and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like
the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the
corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with
diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came
the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came
jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented
with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among
them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried
nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without
noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King\xE2\x80\x99s
crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand
procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.

Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face
like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard
of such a rule at processions; \xE2\x80\x98and besides, what would be the use of
a procession,\xE2\x80\x99 thought she, \xE2\x80\x98if people had all to lie down upon their
faces, so that they couldn\xE2\x80\x99t see it?\xE2\x80\x99 So she stood still where she was,
and waited.

When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked
at her, and the Queen said severely \xE2\x80\x98Who is this?\xE2\x80\x99 She said it to the
Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.

\xE2\x80\x98Idiot!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to
Alice, she went on, \xE2\x80\x98What\xE2\x80\x99s your name, child?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice very politely;
but she added, to herself, \xE2\x80\x98Why, they\xE2\x80\x99re only a pack of cards, after
all. I needn\xE2\x80\x99t be afraid of them!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98And who are THESE?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who
were lying round the rosetree; for, you see, as they were lying on their
faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the
pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or
courtiers, or three of her own children.

\xE2\x80\x98How should I know?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, surprised at her own courage. \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s no
business of MINE.\xE2\x80\x99

The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a
moment like a wild beast, screamed \xE2\x80\x98Off with her head! Off--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Nonsense!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was
silent.

The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said \xE2\x80\x98Consider, my
dear: she is only a child!\xE2\x80\x99

The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave \xE2\x80\x98Turn them
over!\xE2\x80\x99

The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.

\xE2\x80\x98Get up!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three
gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen,
the royal children, and everybody else.

\xE2\x80\x98Leave off that!\xE2\x80\x99 screamed the Queen. \xE2\x80\x98You make me giddy.\xE2\x80\x99 And then,
turning to the rose-tree, she went on, \xE2\x80\x98What HAVE you been doing here?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98May it please your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 said Two, in a very humble tone, going
down on one knee as he spoke, \xE2\x80\x98we were trying--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I see!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses.
\xE2\x80\x98Off with their heads!\xE2\x80\x99 and the procession moved on, three of the
soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran
to Alice for protection.

\xE2\x80\x98You shan\xE2\x80\x99t be beheaded!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, and she put them into a large
flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a
minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the
others.

\xE2\x80\x98Are their heads off?\xE2\x80\x99 shouted the Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!\xE2\x80\x99 the soldiers shouted
in reply.

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s right!\xE2\x80\x99 shouted the Queen. \xE2\x80\x98Can you play croquet?\xE2\x80\x99

The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was
evidently meant for her.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes!\xE2\x80\x99 shouted Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Come on, then!\xE2\x80\x99 roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession,
wondering very much what would happen next.

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s--it\xE2\x80\x99s a very fine day!\xE2\x80\x99 said a timid voice at her side. She was
walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.

\xE2\x80\x98Very,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98--where\xE2\x80\x99s the Duchess?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Hush! Hush!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked
anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon
tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered \xE2\x80\x98She\xE2\x80\x99s under
sentence of execution.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What for?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Did you say \xE2\x80\x9CWhat a pity!\xE2\x80\x9D?\xE2\x80\x99 the Rabbit asked.

\xE2\x80\x98No, I didn\xE2\x80\x99t,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t think it\xE2\x80\x99s at all a pity. I said
\xE2\x80\x9CWhat for?\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98She boxed the Queen\xE2\x80\x99s ears--\xE2\x80\x99 the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little
scream of laughter. \xE2\x80\x98Oh, hush!\xE2\x80\x99 the Rabbit whispered in a frightened
tone. \xE2\x80\x98The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the
Queen said--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Get to your places!\xE2\x80\x99 shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and
people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each
other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game
began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in
her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs,
the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves
up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo:
she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under
her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got
its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a
blow with its head, it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face,
with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out
laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin
again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled
itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was
generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the
hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up
and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the
conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling
all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short
time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and
shouting \xE2\x80\x98Off with his head!\xE2\x80\x99 or \xE2\x80\x98Off with her head!\xE2\x80\x99 about once in a
minute.

Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any
dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute,
\xE2\x80\x98and then,\xE2\x80\x99 thought she, \xE2\x80\x98what would become of me? They\xE2\x80\x99re dreadfully
fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there\xE2\x80\x99s any one
left alive!\xE2\x80\x99

She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she
could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance
in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it
a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself
\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98How are you getting on?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth
enough for it to speak with.

Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s no use
speaking to it,\xE2\x80\x99 she thought, \xE2\x80\x98till its ears have come, or at least one
of them.\xE2\x80\x99 In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put
down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad
she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was
enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t think they play at all fairly,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice began, in rather a
complaining tone, \xE2\x80\x98and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can\xE2\x80\x99t hear
oneself speak--and they don\xE2\x80\x99t seem to have any rules in particular;
at least, if there are, nobody attends to them--and you\xE2\x80\x99ve no idea how
confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there\xE2\x80\x99s the
arch I\xE2\x80\x99ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the
ground--and I should have croqueted the Queen\xE2\x80\x99s hedgehog just now, only
it ran away when it saw mine coming!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98How do you like the Queen?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Cat in a low voice.

\xE2\x80\x98Not at all,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98she\xE2\x80\x99s so extremely--\xE2\x80\x99 Just then she noticed
that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on,
\xE2\x80\x98--likely to win, that it\xE2\x80\x99s hardly worth while finishing the game.\xE2\x80\x99

The Queen smiled and passed on.

\xE2\x80\x98Who ARE you talking to?\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, going up to Alice, and looking
at the Cat\xE2\x80\x99s head with great curiosity.

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s a friend of mine--a Cheshire Cat,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98allow me to
introduce it.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t like the look of it at all,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King: \xE2\x80\x98however, it may
kiss my hand if it likes.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99d rather not,\xE2\x80\x99 the Cat remarked.

\xE2\x80\x98Don\xE2\x80\x99t be impertinent,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, \xE2\x80\x98and don\xE2\x80\x99t look at me like that!\xE2\x80\x99
He got behind Alice as he spoke.

\xE2\x80\x98A cat may look at a king,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve read that in some book,
but I don\xE2\x80\x99t remember where.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, it must be removed,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King very decidedly, and he called
the Queen, who was passing at the moment, \xE2\x80\x98My dear! I wish you would
have this cat removed!\xE2\x80\x99

The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.
\xE2\x80\x98Off with his head!\xE2\x80\x99 she said, without even looking round.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ll fetch the executioner myself,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King eagerly, and he
hurried off.

Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going
on, as she heard the Queen\xE2\x80\x99s voice in the distance, screaming with
passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be
executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look
of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew
whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.

The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed
to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the
other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the
other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless
sort of way to fly up into a tree.

By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight
was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: \xE2\x80\x98but it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t
matter much,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, \xE2\x80\x98as all the arches are gone from this side
of the ground.\xE2\x80\x99 So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not
escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her
friend.

When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a
large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between
the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once,
while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.

The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle
the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they
all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly
what they said.

The executioner\xE2\x80\x99s argument was, that you couldn\xE2\x80\x99t cut off a head unless
there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a
thing before, and he wasn\xE2\x80\x99t going to begin at HIS time of life.

The King\xE2\x80\x99s argument was, that anything that had a head could be
beheaded, and that you weren\xE2\x80\x99t to talk nonsense.

The Queen\xE2\x80\x99s argument was, that if something wasn\xE2\x80\x99t done about it in less
than no time she\xE2\x80\x99d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last
remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)

Alice could think of nothing else to say but \xE2\x80\x98It belongs to the Duchess:
you\xE2\x80\x99d better ask HER about it.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98She\xE2\x80\x99s in prison,\xE2\x80\x99 the Queen said to the executioner: \xE2\x80\x98fetch her here.\xE2\x80\x99
And the executioner went off like an arrow.

 The Cat\xE2\x80\x99s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and,
by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely
disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down
looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.




CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle\xE2\x80\x99s Story

\xE2\x80\x98You can\xE2\x80\x99t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!\xE2\x80\x99
said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice\xE2\x80\x99s, and
they walked off together.

Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought
to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so
savage when they met in the kitchen.

\xE2\x80\x98When I\xE2\x80\x99M a Duchess,\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone
though), \xE2\x80\x98I won\xE2\x80\x99t have any pepper in my kitchen AT ALL. Soup does very
well without--Maybe it\xE2\x80\x99s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,\xE2\x80\x99
she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of
rule, \xE2\x80\x98and vinegar that makes them sour--and camomile that makes
them bitter--and--and barley-sugar and such things that make children
sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t be so
stingy about it, you know--\xE2\x80\x99

She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little
startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. \xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re thinking
about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can\xE2\x80\x99t
tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in
a bit.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Perhaps it hasn\xE2\x80\x99t one,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice ventured to remark.

\xE2\x80\x98Tut, tut, child!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess. \xE2\x80\x98Everything\xE2\x80\x99s got a moral, if only
you can find it.\xE2\x80\x99 And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice\xE2\x80\x99s side as
she spoke.

Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the
Duchess was VERY ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the
right height to rest her chin upon Alice\xE2\x80\x99s shoulder, and it was an
uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she
bore it as well as she could.

\xE2\x80\x98The game\xE2\x80\x99s going on rather better now,\xE2\x80\x99 she said, by way of keeping up
the conversation a little.

\xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x99Tis so,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess: \xE2\x80\x98and the moral of that is--\xE2\x80\x9COh, \xE2\x80\x98tis love,
\xE2\x80\x98tis love, that makes the world go round!\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Somebody said,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice whispered, \xE2\x80\x98that it\xE2\x80\x99s done by everybody minding
their own business!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Ah, well! It means much the same thing,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess, digging her
sharp little chin into Alice\xE2\x80\x99s shoulder as she added, \xE2\x80\x98and the moral
of THAT is--\xE2\x80\x9CTake care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of
themselves.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98How fond she is of finding morals in things!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice thought to herself.

\xE2\x80\x98I dare say you\xE2\x80\x99re wondering why I don\xE2\x80\x99t put my arm round your waist,\xE2\x80\x99
the Duchess said after a pause: \xE2\x80\x98the reason is, that I\xE2\x80\x99m doubtful about
the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98HE might bite,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to
have the experiment tried.

\xE2\x80\x98Very true,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess: \xE2\x80\x98flamingoes and mustard both bite. And
the moral of that is--\xE2\x80\x9CBirds of a feather flock together.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Only mustard isn\xE2\x80\x99t a bird,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice remarked.

\xE2\x80\x98Right, as usual,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess: \xE2\x80\x98what a clear way you have of
putting things!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s a mineral, I THINK,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course it is,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to
everything that Alice said; \xE2\x80\x98there\xE2\x80\x99s a large mustard-mine near here. And
the moral of that is--\xE2\x80\x9CThe more there is of mine, the less there is of
yours.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, I know!\xE2\x80\x99 exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark,
\xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s a vegetable. It doesn\xE2\x80\x99t look like one, but it is.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I quite agree with you,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess; \xE2\x80\x98and the moral of that
is--\xE2\x80\x9CBe what you would seem to be\xE2\x80\x9D--or if you\xE2\x80\x99d like it put more
simply--\xE2\x80\x9CNever imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might
appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise
than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I think I should understand that better,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said very politely, \xE2\x80\x98if
I had it written down: but I can\xE2\x80\x99t quite follow it as you say it.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s nothing to what I could say if I chose,\xE2\x80\x99 the Duchess replied, in
a pleased tone.

\xE2\x80\x98Pray don\xE2\x80\x99t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,\xE2\x80\x99 said
Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, don\xE2\x80\x99t talk about trouble!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess. \xE2\x80\x98I make you a present
of everything I\xE2\x80\x99ve said as yet.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98A cheap sort of present!\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m glad they don\xE2\x80\x99t give
birthday presents like that!\xE2\x80\x99 But she did not venture to say it out
loud.

\xE2\x80\x98Thinking again?\xE2\x80\x99 the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp
little chin.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve a right to think,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to
feel a little worried.

\xE2\x80\x98Just about as much right,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Duchess, \xE2\x80\x98as pigs have to fly; and
the m--\xE2\x80\x99

But here, to Alice\xE2\x80\x99s great surprise, the Duchess\xE2\x80\x99s voice died away, even
in the middle of her favourite word \xE2\x80\x98moral,\xE2\x80\x99 and the arm that was linked
into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen
in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.

\xE2\x80\x98A fine day, your Majesty!\xE2\x80\x99 the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.

\xE2\x80\x98Now, I give you fair warning,\xE2\x80\x99 shouted the Queen, stamping on the
ground as she spoke; \xE2\x80\x98either you or your head must be off, and that in
about half no time! Take your choice!\xE2\x80\x99

The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.

\xE2\x80\x98Let\xE2\x80\x99s go on with the game,\xE2\x80\x99 the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was
too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the
croquet-ground.

The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen\xE2\x80\x99s absence, and were
resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried
back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment\xE2\x80\x99s delay would
cost them their lives.

All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with
the other players, and shouting \xE2\x80\x98Off with his head!\xE2\x80\x99 or \xE2\x80\x98Off with her
head!\xE2\x80\x99 Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers,
who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by
the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the
players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and
under sentence of execution.

Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, \xE2\x80\x98Have
you seen the Mock Turtle yet?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98No,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t even know what a Mock Turtle is.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98I never saw one, or heard of one,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Come on, then,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, \xE2\x80\x98and he shall tell you his history,\xE2\x80\x99

As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice,
to the company generally, \xE2\x80\x98You are all pardoned.\xE2\x80\x99 \xE2\x80\x98Come, THAT\xE2\x80\x99S a good
thing!\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the
number of executions the Queen had ordered.

They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun.
(IF you don\xE2\x80\x99t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) \xE2\x80\x98Up, lazy
thing!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, \xE2\x80\x98and take this young lady to see the Mock
Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some
executions I have ordered\xE2\x80\x99; and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with
the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on
the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go
after that savage Queen: so she waited.

The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till
she was out of sight: then it chuckled. \xE2\x80\x98What fun!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon,
half to itself, half to Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98What IS the fun?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Why, SHE,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon. \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s all her fancy, that: they never
executes nobody, you know. Come on!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Everybody says \xE2\x80\x9Ccome on!\xE2\x80\x9D here,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, as she went slowly
after it: \xE2\x80\x98I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!\xE2\x80\x99

They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance,
sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came
nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She
pitied him deeply. \xE2\x80\x98What is his sorrow?\xE2\x80\x99 she asked the Gryphon, and the
Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, \xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s all his
fancy, that: he hasn\xE2\x80\x99t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!\xE2\x80\x99

So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes
full of tears, but said nothing.

\xE2\x80\x98This here young lady,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon, \xE2\x80\x98she wants for to know your
history, she do.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ll tell it her,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: \xE2\x80\x98sit
down, both of you, and don\xE2\x80\x99t speak a word till I\xE2\x80\x99ve finished.\xE2\x80\x99

So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to
herself, \xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t see how he can EVEN finish, if he doesn\xE2\x80\x99t begin.\xE2\x80\x99 But
she waited patiently.

\xE2\x80\x98Once,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, \xE2\x80\x98I was a real
Turtle.\xE2\x80\x99

These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an
occasional exclamation of \xE2\x80\x98Hjckrrh!\xE2\x80\x99 from the Gryphon, and the constant
heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and
saying, \xE2\x80\x98Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,\xE2\x80\x99 but she could
not help thinking there MUST be more to come, so she sat still and said
nothing.

\xE2\x80\x98When we were little,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly,
though still sobbing a little now and then, \xE2\x80\x98we went to school in the
sea. The master was an old Turtle--we used to call him Tortoise--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn\xE2\x80\x99t one?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice asked.

\xE2\x80\x98We called him Tortoise because he taught us,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle
angrily: \xE2\x80\x98really you are very dull!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,\xE2\x80\x99
added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor
Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said
to the Mock Turtle, \xE2\x80\x98Drive on, old fellow! Don\xE2\x80\x99t be all day about it!\xE2\x80\x99
and he went on in these words:

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn\xE2\x80\x99t believe it--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I never said I didn\xE2\x80\x99t!\xE2\x80\x99 interrupted Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98You did,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98Hold your tongue!\xE2\x80\x99 added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again.
The Mock Turtle went on.

\xE2\x80\x98We had the best of educations--in fact, we went to school every day--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99VE been to a day-school, too,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98you needn\xE2\x80\x99t be so proud
as all that.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98With extras?\xE2\x80\x99 asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

\xE2\x80\x98Yes,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98we learned French and music.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98And washing?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98Certainly not!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice indignantly.

\xE2\x80\x98Ah! then yours wasn\xE2\x80\x99t a really good school,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle in
a tone of great relief. \xE2\x80\x98Now at OURS they had at the end of the bill,
\xE2\x80\x9CFrench, music, AND WASHING--extra.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You couldn\xE2\x80\x99t have wanted it much,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice; \xE2\x80\x98living at the bottom of
the sea.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I couldn\xE2\x80\x99t afford to learn it.\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. \xE2\x80\x98I
only took the regular course.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What was that?\xE2\x80\x99 inquired Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle
replied; \xE2\x80\x98and then the different branches of Arithmetic--Ambition,
Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I never heard of \xE2\x80\x9CUglification,\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99 Alice ventured to say. \xE2\x80\x98What is it?\xE2\x80\x99

The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. \xE2\x80\x98What! Never heard of
uglifying!\xE2\x80\x99 it exclaimed. \xE2\x80\x98You know what to beautify is, I suppose?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Yes,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice doubtfully: \xE2\x80\x98it means--to--make--anything--prettier.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, then,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon went on, \xE2\x80\x98if you don\xE2\x80\x99t know what to uglify is,
you ARE a simpleton.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she
turned to the Mock Turtle, and said \xE2\x80\x98What else had you to learn?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, there was Mystery,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle replied, counting off
the subjects on his flappers, \xE2\x80\x98--Mystery, ancient and modern, with
Seaography: then Drawling--the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel,
that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and
Fainting in Coils.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What was THAT like?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I can\xE2\x80\x99t show it you myself,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle said: \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m too
stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Hadn\xE2\x80\x99t time,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon: \xE2\x80\x98I went to the Classics master, though.
He was an old crab, HE was.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I never went to him,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: \xE2\x80\x98he taught
Laughing and Grief, they used to say.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98So he did, so he did,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both
creatures hid their faces in their paws.

\xE2\x80\x98And how many hours a day did you do lessons?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, in a hurry to
change the subject.

\xE2\x80\x98Ten hours the first day,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle: \xE2\x80\x98nine the next, and so
on.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What a curious plan!\xE2\x80\x99 exclaimed Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s the reason they\xE2\x80\x99re called lessons,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon remarked:
\xE2\x80\x98because they lessen from day to day.\xE2\x80\x99

This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little
before she made her next remark. \xE2\x80\x98Then the eleventh day must have been a
holiday?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Of course it was,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98And how did you manage on the twelfth?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice went on eagerly.

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s enough about lessons,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided
tone: \xE2\x80\x98tell her something about the games now.\xE2\x80\x99




CHAPTER X. The Lobster Quadrille

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across
his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or
two sobs choked his voice. \xE2\x80\x98Same as if he had a bone in his throat,\xE2\x80\x99
said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in
the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears
running down his cheeks, he went on again:--

\xE2\x80\x98You may not have lived much under the sea--\xE2\x80\x99 [\xE2\x80\x98I haven\xE2\x80\x99t,\xE2\x80\x99 said
Alice)--\xE2\x80\x98and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster--\xE2\x80\x99
(Alice began to say \xE2\x80\x98I once tasted--\xE2\x80\x99 but checked herself hastily, and
said \xE2\x80\x98No, never\xE2\x80\x99) \xE2\x80\x98--so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a
Lobster Quadrille is!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98No, indeed,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98What sort of a dance is it?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Why,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon, \xE2\x80\x98you first form into a line along the
sea-shore--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Two lines!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Mock Turtle. \xE2\x80\x98Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on;
then, when you\xE2\x80\x99ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98THAT generally takes some time,\xE2\x80\x99 interrupted the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98--you advance twice--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Each with a lobster as a partner!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle said: \xE2\x80\x98advance twice, set to partners--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98--change lobsters, and retire in same order,\xE2\x80\x99 continued the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98Then, you know,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle went on, \xE2\x80\x98you throw the--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98The lobsters!\xE2\x80\x99 shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.

\xE2\x80\x98--as far out to sea as you can--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Swim after them!\xE2\x80\x99 screamed the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98Turn a somersault in the sea!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly
about.

\xE2\x80\x98Change lobsters again!\xE2\x80\x99 yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.

\xE2\x80\x98Back to land again, and that\xE2\x80\x99s all the first figure,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock
Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been
jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly
and quietly, and looked at Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98It must be a very pretty dance,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice timidly.

\xE2\x80\x98Would you like to see a little of it?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98Very much indeed,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Come, let\xE2\x80\x99s try the first figure!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon.
\xE2\x80\x98We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, YOU sing,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve forgotten the words.\xE2\x80\x99

So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and
then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their
forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly
and sadly:--

 \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x9CWill you walk a little faster?\xE2\x80\x9D said a whiting to a snail.
 \xE2\x80\x9CThere\xE2\x80\x99s a porpoise close behind us, and he\xE2\x80\x99s treading on my tail.

 See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
 They are waiting on the shingle--will you come and join the dance?

 Will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you join the dance?

 \xE2\x80\x9CYou can really have no notion how delightful it will be
 When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!\xE2\x80\x9D
  But the snail replied \xE2\x80\x9CToo far, too far!\xE2\x80\x9D and gave a look askance--
 Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.

 Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
 Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

 \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x9CWhat matters it how far we go?\xE2\x80\x9D his scaly friend replied.
 \xE2\x80\x9CThere is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
 The further off from England the nearer is to France--
 Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.

 Will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, will you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you, won\xE2\x80\x99t you join the dance?\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Thank you, it\xE2\x80\x99s a very interesting dance to watch,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, feeling
very glad that it was over at last: \xE2\x80\x98and I do so like that curious song
about the whiting!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, as to the whiting,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle, \xE2\x80\x98they--you\xE2\x80\x99ve seen them,
of course?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Yes,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve often seen them at dinn--\xE2\x80\x99 she checked herself
hastily.

\xE2\x80\x98I don\xE2\x80\x99t know where Dinn may be,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle, \xE2\x80\x98but if you\xE2\x80\x99ve
seen them so often, of course you know what they\xE2\x80\x99re like.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I believe so,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice replied thoughtfully. \xE2\x80\x98They have their tails in
their mouths--and they\xE2\x80\x99re all over crumbs.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re wrong about the crumbs,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle: \xE2\x80\x98crumbs would all
wash off in the sea. But they HAVE their tails in their mouths; and the
reason is--\xE2\x80\x99 here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.--\xE2\x80\x98Tell her
about the reason and all that,\xE2\x80\x99 he said to the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98The reason is,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon, \xE2\x80\x98that they WOULD go with the lobsters
to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long
way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn\xE2\x80\x99t get
them out again. That\xE2\x80\x99s all.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Thank you,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, \xE2\x80\x98it\xE2\x80\x99s very interesting. I never knew so much
about a whiting before.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I can tell you more than that, if you like,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon. \xE2\x80\x98Do you
know why it\xE2\x80\x99s called a whiting?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I never thought about it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98Why?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98IT DOES THE BOOTS AND SHOES.\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon replied very solemnly.

Alice was thoroughly puzzled. \xE2\x80\x98Does the boots and shoes!\xE2\x80\x99 she repeated
in a wondering tone.

\xE2\x80\x98Why, what are YOUR shoes done with?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon. \xE2\x80\x98I mean, what
makes them so shiny?\xE2\x80\x99

Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her
answer. \xE2\x80\x98They\xE2\x80\x99re done with blacking, I believe.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Boots and shoes under the sea,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon went on in a deep voice,
\xE2\x80\x98are done with a whiting. Now you know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98And what are they made of?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.

\xE2\x80\x98Soles and eels, of course,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon replied rather impatiently:
\xE2\x80\x98any shrimp could have told you that.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98If I\xE2\x80\x99d been the whiting,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, whose thoughts were still running
on the song, \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99d have said to the porpoise, \xE2\x80\x9CKeep back, please: we
don\xE2\x80\x99t want YOU with us!\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98They were obliged to have him with them,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle said: \xE2\x80\x98no
wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t it really?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice in a tone of great surprise.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course not,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle: \xE2\x80\x98why, if a fish came to ME, and
told me he was going a journey, I should say \xE2\x80\x9CWith what porpoise?\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Don\xE2\x80\x99t you mean \xE2\x80\x9Cpurpose\xE2\x80\x9D?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98I mean what I say,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And
the Gryphon added \xE2\x80\x98Come, let\xE2\x80\x99s hear some of YOUR adventures.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I could tell you my adventures--beginning from this morning,\xE2\x80\x99 said
Alice a little timidly: \xE2\x80\x98but it\xE2\x80\x99s no use going back to yesterday,
because I was a different person then.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Explain all that,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98No, no! The adventures first,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon in an impatient tone:
\xE2\x80\x98explanations take such a dreadful time.\xE2\x80\x99

So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first
saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first,
the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened
their eyes and mouths so VERY wide, but she gained courage as she went
on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about
her repeating \xE2\x80\x98YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,\xE2\x80\x99 to the Caterpillar, and the
words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath,
and said \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s very curious.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s all about as curious as it can be,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98It all came different!\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. \xE2\x80\x98I
should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to
begin.\xE2\x80\x99 He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of
authority over Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Stand up and repeat \xE2\x80\x9C\xE2\x80\x98TIS THE VOICE OF THE SLUGGARD,\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99 said the
Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!\xE2\x80\x99
thought Alice; \xE2\x80\x98I might as well be at school at once.\xE2\x80\x99 However, she
got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster
Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came
very queer indeed:--

  \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x99Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
  \xE2\x80\x9CYou have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.\xE2\x80\x9D
   As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
  Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.\xE2\x80\x99

       [later editions continued as follows
  When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark,
  And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark,
  But, when the tide rises and sharks are around,
  His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s different from what I used to say when I was a child,\xE2\x80\x99 said the
Gryphon.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I never heard it before,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle; \xE2\x80\x98but it sounds
uncommon nonsense.\xE2\x80\x99

Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands,
wondering if anything would EVER happen in a natural way again.

\xE2\x80\x98I should like to have it explained,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Mock Turtle.

\xE2\x80\x98She can\xE2\x80\x99t explain it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon hastily. \xE2\x80\x98Go on with the next
verse.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But about his toes?\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle persisted. \xE2\x80\x98How COULD he turn them
out with his nose, you know?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s the first position in dancing.\xE2\x80\x99 Alice said; but was dreadfully
puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.

\xE2\x80\x98Go on with the next verse,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon repeated impatiently: \xE2\x80\x98it
begins \xE2\x80\x9CI passed by his garden.\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99

Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come
wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:--

  \xE2\x80\x98I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
  How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie--\xE2\x80\x99

    [later editions continued as follows
  The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
  While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat.
  When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon,
  Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon:
  While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl,
  And concluded the banquet--]

\xE2\x80\x98What IS the use of repeating all that stuff,\xE2\x80\x99 the Mock Turtle
interrupted, \xE2\x80\x98if you don\xE2\x80\x99t explain it as you go on? It\xE2\x80\x99s by far the most
confusing thing I ever heard!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, I think you\xE2\x80\x99d better leave off,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Gryphon: and Alice was
only too glad to do so.

\xE2\x80\x98Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon went
on. \xE2\x80\x98Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,\xE2\x80\x99 Alice
replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone,
\xE2\x80\x98Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her \xE2\x80\x9CTurtle Soup,\xE2\x80\x9D will you, old
fellow?\xE2\x80\x99

The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked
with sobs, to sing this:--

   \xE2\x80\x98Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
   Waiting in a hot tureen!
   Who for such dainties would not stoop?
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
     Beau--ootiful Soo--oop!
     Beau--ootiful Soo--oop!
   Soo--oop of the e--e--evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!

   \xE2\x80\x98Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
   Game, or any other dish?
   Who would not give all else for two
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
     Beau--ootiful Soo--oop!
     Beau--ootiful Soo--oop!
   Soo--oop of the e--e--evening,
     Beautiful, beauti--FUL SOUP!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Chorus again!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun
to repeat it, when a cry of \xE2\x80\x98The trial\xE2\x80\x99s beginning!\xE2\x80\x99 was heard in the
distance.

\xE2\x80\x98Come on!\xE2\x80\x99 cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried
off, without waiting for the end of the song.

\xE2\x80\x98What trial is it?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only
answered \xE2\x80\x98Come on!\xE2\x80\x99 and ran the faster, while more and more faintly
came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:--

   \xE2\x80\x98Soo--oop of the e--e--evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!\xE2\x80\x99




CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they
arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them--all sorts of little
birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was
standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard
him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand,
and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court
was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good,
that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them--\xE2\x80\x98I wish they\xE2\x80\x99d get the
trial done,\xE2\x80\x99 she thought, \xE2\x80\x98and hand round the refreshments!\xE2\x80\x99 But there
seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about
her, to pass away the time.

Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read
about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew
the name of nearly everything there. \xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s the judge,\xE2\x80\x99 she said to
herself, \xE2\x80\x98because of his great wig.\xE2\x80\x99

The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the
wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did
not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.

\xE2\x80\x98And that\xE2\x80\x99s the jury-box,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice, \xE2\x80\x98and those twelve creatures,\xE2\x80\x99
(she was obliged to say \xE2\x80\x98creatures,\xE2\x80\x99 you see, because some of them were
animals, and some were birds,) \xE2\x80\x98I suppose they are the jurors.\xE2\x80\x99 She said
this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of
it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her
age knew the meaning of it at all. However, \xE2\x80\x98jury-men\xE2\x80\x99 would have done
just as well.

The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. \xE2\x80\x98What are they
doing?\xE2\x80\x99 Alice whispered to the Gryphon. \xE2\x80\x98They can\xE2\x80\x99t have anything to put
down yet, before the trial\xE2\x80\x99s begun.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98They\xE2\x80\x99re putting down their names,\xE2\x80\x99 the Gryphon whispered in reply, \xE2\x80\x98for
fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Stupid things!\xE2\x80\x99 Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped
hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, \xE2\x80\x98Silence in the court!\xE2\x80\x99 and the
King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who
was talking.

Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders,
that all the jurors were writing down \xE2\x80\x98stupid things!\xE2\x80\x99 on their slates,
and she could even make out that one of them didn\xE2\x80\x99t know how to spell
\xE2\x80\x98stupid,\xE2\x80\x99 and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. \xE2\x80\x98A nice
muddle their slates\xE2\x80\x99ll be in before the trial\xE2\x80\x99s over!\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice.

One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice
could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and
very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly
that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out
at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was
obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was
of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.

\xE2\x80\x98Herald, read the accusation!\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then
unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:--

   \xE2\x80\x98The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
      All on a summer day:
    The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
      And took them quite away!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Consider your verdict,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said to the jury.

\xE2\x80\x98Not yet, not yet!\xE2\x80\x99 the Rabbit hastily interrupted. \xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s a great
deal to come before that!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Call the first witness,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three
blasts on the trumpet, and called out, \xE2\x80\x98First witness!\xE2\x80\x99

The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one
hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. \xE2\x80\x98I beg pardon, your
Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 he began, \xE2\x80\x98for bringing these in: but I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t quite finished
my tea when I was sent for.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You ought to have finished,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King. \xE2\x80\x98When did you begin?\xE2\x80\x99

The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the
court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. \xE2\x80\x98Fourteenth of March, I think it
was,\xE2\x80\x99 he said.

\xE2\x80\x98Fifteenth,\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98Sixteenth,\xE2\x80\x99 added the Dormouse.

\xE2\x80\x98Write that down,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly
wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and
reduced the answer to shillings and pence.

\xE2\x80\x98Take off your hat,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said to the Hatter.

\xE2\x80\x98It isn\xE2\x80\x99t mine,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

\xE2\x80\x98Stolen!\xE2\x80\x99 the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a
memorandum of the fact.

\xE2\x80\x98I keep them to sell,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter added as an explanation; \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve none of
my own. I\xE2\x80\x99m a hatter.\xE2\x80\x99

Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter,
who turned pale and fidgeted.

\xE2\x80\x98Give your evidence,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King; \xE2\x80\x98and don\xE2\x80\x99t be nervous, or I\xE2\x80\x99ll have
you executed on the spot.\xE2\x80\x99

This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting
from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in
his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the
bread-and-butter.

Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled
her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to
grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave
the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as
long as there was room for her.

\xE2\x80\x98I wish you wouldn\xE2\x80\x99t squeeze so.\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse, who was sitting
next to her. \xE2\x80\x98I can hardly breathe.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I can\xE2\x80\x99t help it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice very meekly: \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m growing.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99ve no right to grow here,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse.

\xE2\x80\x98Don\xE2\x80\x99t talk nonsense,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice more boldly: \xE2\x80\x98you know you\xE2\x80\x99re growing
too.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Dormouse: \xE2\x80\x98not in that
ridiculous fashion.\xE2\x80\x99 And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the
other side of the court.

All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and,
just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers
of the court, \xE2\x80\x98Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!\xE2\x80\x99 on
which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

\xE2\x80\x98Give your evidence,\xE2\x80\x99 the King repeated angrily, \xE2\x80\x98or I\xE2\x80\x99ll have you
executed, whether you\xE2\x80\x99re nervous or not.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m a poor man, your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter began, in a trembling voice,
\xE2\x80\x98--and I hadn\xE2\x80\x99t begun my tea--not above a week or so--and what with the
bread-and-butter getting so thin--and the twinkling of the tea--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98The twinkling of the what?\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

\xE2\x80\x98It began with the tea,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter replied.

\xE2\x80\x98Of course twinkling begins with a T!\xE2\x80\x99 said the King sharply. \xE2\x80\x98Do you
take me for a dunce? Go on!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m a poor man,\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter went on, \xE2\x80\x98and most things twinkled after
that--only the March Hare said--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I didn\xE2\x80\x99t!\xE2\x80\x99 the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.

\xE2\x80\x98You did!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

\xE2\x80\x98I deny it!\xE2\x80\x99 said the March Hare.

\xE2\x80\x98He denies it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King: \xE2\x80\x98leave out that part.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said--\xE2\x80\x99 the Hatter went on, looking
anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied
nothing, being fast asleep.

\xE2\x80\x98After that,\xE2\x80\x99 continued the Hatter, \xE2\x80\x98I cut some more bread-and-butter--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But what did the Dormouse say?\xE2\x80\x99 one of the jury asked.

\xE2\x80\x98That I can\xE2\x80\x99t remember,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter.

\xE2\x80\x98You MUST remember,\xE2\x80\x99 remarked the King, \xE2\x80\x98or I\xE2\x80\x99ll have you executed.\xE2\x80\x99

The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went
down on one knee. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m a poor man, your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 he began.

\xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re a very poor speaker,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by
the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just
explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied
up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig,
head first, and then sat upon it.)

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m glad I\xE2\x80\x99ve seen that done,\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ve so often read
in the newspapers, at the end of trials, \xE2\x80\x9CThere was some attempts
at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the
court,\xE2\x80\x9D and I never understood what it meant till now.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98If that\xE2\x80\x99s all you know about it, you may stand down,\xE2\x80\x99 continued the
King.

\xE2\x80\x98I can\xE2\x80\x99t go no lower,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter: \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99m on the floor, as it is.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Then you may SIT down,\xE2\x80\x99 the King replied.

Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.

\xE2\x80\x98Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!\xE2\x80\x99 thought Alice. \xE2\x80\x98Now we shall get
on better.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99d rather finish my tea,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the
Queen, who was reading the list of singers.

\xE2\x80\x98You may go,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court,
without even waiting to put his shoes on.

\xE2\x80\x98--and just take his head off outside,\xE2\x80\x99 the Queen added to one of the
officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get
to the door.

\xE2\x80\x98Call the next witness!\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

The next witness was the Duchess\xE2\x80\x99s cook. She carried the pepper-box in
her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the
court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.

\xE2\x80\x98Give your evidence,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

\xE2\x80\x98Shan\xE2\x80\x99t,\xE2\x80\x99 said the cook.

The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice,
\xE2\x80\x98Your Majesty must cross-examine THIS witness.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Well, if I must, I must,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said, with a melancholy air, and,
after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were
nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, \xE2\x80\x98What are tarts made of?\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Pepper, mostly,\xE2\x80\x99 said the cook.

\xE2\x80\x98Treacle,\xE2\x80\x99 said a sleepy voice behind her.

\xE2\x80\x98Collar that Dormouse,\xE2\x80\x99 the Queen shrieked out. \xE2\x80\x98Behead that Dormouse!
Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his
whiskers!\xE2\x80\x99

For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse
turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had
disappeared.

\xE2\x80\x98Never mind!\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, with an air of great relief. \xE2\x80\x98Call the next
witness.\xE2\x80\x99 And he added in an undertone to the Queen, \xE2\x80\x98Really, my dear,
YOU must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead
ache!\xE2\x80\x99

Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very
curious to see what the next witness would be like, \xE2\x80\x98--for they haven\xE2\x80\x99t
got much evidence YET,\xE2\x80\x99 she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when
the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the
name \xE2\x80\x98Alice!\xE2\x80\x99




CHAPTER XII. Alice\xE2\x80\x99s Evidence


\xE2\x80\x98Here!\xE2\x80\x99 cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how
large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such
a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt,
upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there
they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish
she had accidentally upset the week before.

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, I BEG your pardon!\xE2\x80\x99 she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and
began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of
the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea
that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or
they would die.

\xE2\x80\x98The trial cannot proceed,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King in a very grave voice, \xE2\x80\x98until
all the jurymen are back in their proper places--ALL,\xE2\x80\x99 he repeated with
great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said do.

Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put
the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its
tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got
it out again, and put it right; \xE2\x80\x98not that it signifies much,\xE2\x80\x99 she said
to herself; \xE2\x80\x98I should think it would be QUITE as much use in the trial
one way up as the other.\xE2\x80\x99

As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being
upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to
them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the
accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do
anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the
court.

\xE2\x80\x98What do you know about this business?\xE2\x80\x99 the King said to Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Nothing,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Nothing WHATEVER?\xE2\x80\x99 persisted the King.

\xE2\x80\x98Nothing whatever,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s very important,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said, turning to the jury. They were
just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit
interrupted: \xE2\x80\x98UNimportant, your Majesty means, of course,\xE2\x80\x99 he said in a
very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.

\xE2\x80\x98UNimportant, of course, I meant,\xE2\x80\x99 the King hastily said, and went on
to himself in an undertone,

\xE2\x80\x98important--unimportant--unimportant--important--\xE2\x80\x99 as if he were trying
which word sounded best.

Some of the jury wrote it down \xE2\x80\x98important,\xE2\x80\x99 and some \xE2\x80\x98unimportant.\xE2\x80\x99
Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates;
\xE2\x80\x98but it doesn\xE2\x80\x99t matter a bit,\xE2\x80\x99 she thought to herself.

At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in
his note-book, cackled out \xE2\x80\x98Silence!\xE2\x80\x99 and read out from his book, \xE2\x80\x98Rule
Forty-two. ALL PERSONS MORE THAN A MILE HIGH TO LEAVE THE COURT.\xE2\x80\x99

Everybody looked at Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99M not a mile high,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98You are,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

\xE2\x80\x98Nearly two miles high,\xE2\x80\x99 added the Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98Well, I shan\xE2\x80\x99t go, at any rate,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice: \xE2\x80\x98besides, that\xE2\x80\x99s not a
regular rule: you invented it just now.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s the oldest rule in the book,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

\xE2\x80\x98Then it ought to be Number One,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. \xE2\x80\x98Consider your
verdict,\xE2\x80\x99 he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

\xE2\x80\x98There\xE2\x80\x99s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 said the White
Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; \xE2\x80\x98this paper has just been picked
up.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98What\xE2\x80\x99s in it?\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98I haven\xE2\x80\x99t opened it yet,\xE2\x80\x99 said the White Rabbit, \xE2\x80\x98but it seems to be a
letter, written by the prisoner to--to somebody.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98It must have been that,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, \xE2\x80\x98unless it was written to
nobody, which isn\xE2\x80\x99t usual, you know.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Who is it directed to?\xE2\x80\x99 said one of the jurymen.

\xE2\x80\x98It isn\xE2\x80\x99t directed at all,\xE2\x80\x99 said the White Rabbit; \xE2\x80\x98in fact, there\xE2\x80\x99s
nothing written on the OUTSIDE.\xE2\x80\x99 He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and
added \xE2\x80\x98It isn\xE2\x80\x99t a letter, after all: it\xE2\x80\x99s a set of verses.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Are they in the prisoner\xE2\x80\x99s handwriting?\xE2\x80\x99 asked another of the jurymen.

\xE2\x80\x98No, they\xE2\x80\x99re not,\xE2\x80\x99 said the White Rabbit, \xE2\x80\x98and that\xE2\x80\x99s the queerest thing
about it.\xE2\x80\x99 (The jury all looked puzzled.)

\xE2\x80\x98He must have imitated somebody else\xE2\x80\x99s hand,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King. (The jury
all brightened up again.)

\xE2\x80\x98Please your Majesty,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Knave, \xE2\x80\x98I didn\xE2\x80\x99t write it, and they
can\xE2\x80\x99t prove I did: there\xE2\x80\x99s no name signed at the end.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98If you didn\xE2\x80\x99t sign it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, \xE2\x80\x98that only makes the matter
worse. You MUST have meant some mischief, or else you\xE2\x80\x99d have signed your
name like an honest man.\xE2\x80\x99

There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really
clever thing the King had said that day.

\xE2\x80\x98That PROVES his guilt,\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98It proves nothing of the sort!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice. \xE2\x80\x98Why, you don\xE2\x80\x99t even know
what they\xE2\x80\x99re about!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Read them,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King.

The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. \xE2\x80\x98Where shall I begin, please
your Majesty?\xE2\x80\x99 he asked.

\xE2\x80\x98Begin at the beginning,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said gravely, \xE2\x80\x98and go on till you
come to the end: then stop.\xE2\x80\x99

These were the verses the White Rabbit read:--

   \xE2\x80\x98They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
   She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

   He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
   If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

   I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
   They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

   If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
   He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

   My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
   An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

   Don\xE2\x80\x99t let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
   A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98That\xE2\x80\x99s the most important piece of evidence we\xE2\x80\x99ve heard yet,\xE2\x80\x99 said the
King, rubbing his hands; \xE2\x80\x98so now let the jury--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98If any one of them can explain it,\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, (she had grown so large
in the last few minutes that she wasn\xE2\x80\x99t a bit afraid of interrupting
him,) \xE2\x80\x98I\xE2\x80\x99ll give him sixpence. _I_ don\xE2\x80\x99t believe there\xE2\x80\x99s an atom of
meaning in it.\xE2\x80\x99

The jury all wrote down on their slates, \xE2\x80\x98SHE doesn\xE2\x80\x99t believe there\xE2\x80\x99s an
atom of meaning in it,\xE2\x80\x99 but none of them attempted to explain the paper.

\xE2\x80\x98If there\xE2\x80\x99s no meaning in it,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, \xE2\x80\x98that saves a world of
trouble, you know, as we needn\xE2\x80\x99t try to find any. And yet I don\xE2\x80\x99t know,\xE2\x80\x99
he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them
with one eye; \xE2\x80\x98I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. \xE2\x80\x9C--SAID
I COULD NOT SWIM--\xE2\x80\x9D you can\xE2\x80\x99t swim, can you?\xE2\x80\x99 he added, turning to the
Knave.

The Knave shook his head sadly. \xE2\x80\x98Do I look like it?\xE2\x80\x99 he said. (Which he
certainly did NOT, being made entirely of cardboard.)

\xE2\x80\x98All right, so far,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, and he went on muttering over
the verses to himself: \xE2\x80\x98\xE2\x80\x9CWE KNOW IT TO BE TRUE--\xE2\x80\x9D that\xE2\x80\x99s the jury, of
course--\xE2\x80\x9CI GAVE HER ONE, THEY GAVE HIM TWO--\xE2\x80\x9D why, that must be what he
did with the tarts, you know--\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98But, it goes on \xE2\x80\x9CTHEY ALL RETURNED FROM HIM TO YOU,\xE2\x80\x9D\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Why, there they are!\xE2\x80\x99 said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts
on the table. \xE2\x80\x98Nothing can be clearer than THAT. Then again--\xE2\x80\x9CBEFORE SHE
HAD THIS FIT--\xE2\x80\x9D you never had fits, my dear, I think?\xE2\x80\x99 he said to the
Queen.

\xE2\x80\x98Never!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard
as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his
slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily
began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as
it lasted.)

\xE2\x80\x98Then the words don\xE2\x80\x99t FIT you,\xE2\x80\x99 said the King, looking round the court
with a smile. There was a dead silence.

\xE2\x80\x98It\xE2\x80\x99s a pun!\xE2\x80\x99 the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed,
\xE2\x80\x98Let the jury consider their verdict,\xE2\x80\x99 the King said, for about the
twentieth time that day.

\xE2\x80\x98No, no!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen. \xE2\x80\x98Sentence first--verdict afterwards.\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Stuff and nonsense!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice loudly. \xE2\x80\x98The idea of having the
sentence first!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Hold your tongue!\xE2\x80\x99 said the Queen, turning purple.

\xE2\x80\x98I won\xE2\x80\x99t!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice.

\xE2\x80\x98Off with her head!\xE2\x80\x99 the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody
moved.

\xE2\x80\x98Who cares for you?\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this
time.) \xE2\x80\x98You\xE2\x80\x99re nothing but a pack of cards!\xE2\x80\x99

At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon
her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and
tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her
head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead
leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.

\xE2\x80\x98Wake up, Alice dear!\xE2\x80\x99 said her sister; \xE2\x80\x98Why, what a long sleep you\xE2\x80\x99ve
had!\xE2\x80\x99

\xE2\x80\x98Oh, I\xE2\x80\x99ve had such a curious dream!\xE2\x80\x99 said Alice, and she told her
sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures
of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had
finished, her sister kissed her, and said, \xE2\x80\x98It WAS a curious dream,
dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it\xE2\x80\x99s getting late.\xE2\x80\x99 So
Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might,
what a wonderful dream it had been.

But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her
hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her
wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and
this was her dream:--

First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny
hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking
up into hers--she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that
queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that
WOULD always get into her eyes--and still as she listened, or seemed to
listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures
of her little sister\xE2\x80\x99s dream.

The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by--the
frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool--she
could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends
shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen
ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution--once more the pig-baby
was sneezing on the Duchess\xE2\x80\x99s knee, while plates and dishes crashed
around it--once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the
Lizard\xE2\x80\x99s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs,
filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock
Turtle.

So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in
Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all
would change to dull reality--the grass would be only rustling in the
wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds--the rattling
teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen\xE2\x80\x99s shrill
cries to the voice of the shepherd boy--and the sneeze of the baby, the
shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she
knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard--while the lowing
of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle\xE2\x80\x99s
heavy sobs.

Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers
would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would
keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her
childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and
make THEIR eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even
with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with
all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys,
remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.

              THE END

Produced by Judith Boss, Christy Phillips, Lynn Hanninen,

Frankenstein,

or the Modern Prometheus


by

Mary Wollstonecraft (Godwin) Shelley




Letter 1


St. Petersburgh, Dec. 11th, 17--

TO Mrs. Saville, England

You will rejoice to hear that no disaster has accompanied the
commencement of an enterprise which you have regarded with such evil
forebodings.  I arrived here yesterday, and my first task is to assure
my dear sister of my welfare and increasing confidence in the success
of my undertaking.

I am already far north of London, and as I walk in the streets of
Petersburgh, I feel a cold northern breeze play upon my cheeks, which
braces my nerves and fills me with delight.  Do you understand this
feeling?  This breeze, which has travelled from the regions towards
which I am advancing, gives me a foretaste of those icy climes.
Inspirited by this wind of promise, my daydreams become more fervent
and vivid.  I try in vain to be persuaded that the pole is the seat of
frost and desolation; it ever presents itself to my imagination as the
region of beauty and delight.  There, Margaret, the sun is forever
visible, its broad disk just skirting the horizon and diffusing a
perpetual splendour.  There--for with your leave, my sister, I will put
some trust in preceding navigators--there snow and frost are banished;
and, sailing over a calm sea, we may be wafted to a land surpassing in
wonders and in beauty every region hitherto discovered on the habitable
globe.  Its productions and features may be without example, as the
phenomena of the heavenly bodies undoubtedly are in those undiscovered
solitudes.  What may not be expected in a country of eternal light?  I
may there discover the wondrous power which attracts the needle and may
regulate a thousand celestial observations that require only this
voyage to render their seeming eccentricities consistent forever.  I
shall satiate my ardent curiosity with the sight of a part of the world
never before visited, and may tread a land never before imprinted by
the foot of man. These are my enticements, and they are sufficient to
conquer all fear of danger or death and to induce me to commence this
laborious voyage with the joy a child feels when he embarks in a little
boat, with his holiday mates, on an expedition of discovery up his
native river. But supposing all these conjectures to be false, you
cannot contest the inestimable benefit which I shall confer on all
mankind, to the last generation, by discovering a passage near the pole
to those countries, to reach which at present so many months are
requisite; or by ascertaining the secret of the magnet, which, if at
all possible, can only be effected by an undertaking such as mine.

These reflections have dispelled the agitation with which I began my
letter, and I feel my heart glow with an enthusiasm which elevates me
to heaven, for nothing contributes so much to tranquillize the mind as
a steady purpose--a point on which the soul may fix its intellectual
eye.  This expedition has been the favourite dream of my early years. I
have read with ardour the accounts of the various voyages which have
been made in the prospect of arriving at the North Pacific Ocean
through the seas which surround the pole.  You may remember that a
history of all the voyages made for purposes of discovery composed the
whole of our good Uncle Thomas' library.  My education was neglected,
yet I was passionately fond of reading.  These volumes were my study
day and night, and my familiarity with them increased that regret which
I had felt, as a child, on learning that my father's dying injunction
had forbidden my uncle to allow me to embark in a seafaring life.

These visions faded when I perused, for the first time, those poets
whose effusions entranced my soul and lifted it to heaven.  I also
became a poet and for one year lived in a paradise of my own creation;
